div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the two Louelesses, Sauill the Steward, and a Page.

sp.speaker: Eld. Lou.
sp.p: BRother, is your last hope past to mollifie Moorecrafts heart about your Morgage?

sp.speaker: Yong. Loue.
sp.p: Hopelesly past: I haue presented the Vsurer with a richer draught, then euer Cleopatra swallowed; he hath suckt in ten thousand pownds worth of my Land, more then hee paid for at a gulpe, without Trumpets.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I haue as hard a task to performe in this house.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Faith mine was to make a Vserer honest, or to loose my land.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: And mine is to perswade a passionate woman, or to leaue the Land.
Sauill make the boate stay, I feare I shall begin my vnfortunate iourney this night, though the darkenesse of the night and the roughnes of the waters might easily disswade an vnwilling man.

sp.speaker: Sauil.
sp.p: Sir, your fathers old friends hold it the sounder course for your body and estate, to stay at home, and marry, and propagate, and gouerne in your Countrey, then to trauell for diseases, and returne following the Court in a nightcap, and die without issue.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p:
Sauill, you shall gaine the opinion of a better
seruant, in seeking to execute, not alter my will, how soeuer my intents succeede.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Yonders Mistres Yongloue brother, the graue rubber of your mistres toes.

div.stage: Enter Mistres Yongloue the waiting woman.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Mistres Yongloue.

sp.speaker: Yong.
sp.p: Mr. Louelesse, truly wee thought your sailes had beene hoist: my Mistres is perswaded you are Sea-sicke ere this.

sp.speaker: El Lo.
sp.p: Loues she her ill taken vp resolution so dearely? Didst thou moue her for me?

sp.speaker: Yong.
sp.p: By this light that shines, thers no remouing her, if she get a stiffe opinion by the end. I attempted her to day when they say a woman can deny nothing.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: What criticall minute was that?

sp.speaker: Yong.
sp.p: When her smock was ouer her eares: but shee was no more pliant then if it hung about her heeles.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I prethee deliuer my seruice, and say I desire to see the deere cause of my banishment; and then for France.

sp.speaker: Yong.
sp.p: Ile doe't: harke hether, is that your Brother?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Yes, haue you lost your memory?

sp.speaker: Yong.
sp.p: As I liue hee's a pretty fellow.

sp.speaker: Yo Lo.
sp.p: O this is a sweete Brache.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Why she knows not you.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: No, but she offered me once to know her: to this day she loues youth of eighteene; she heard a tale how Cupid strooke her in loue with a great Lord in the Tilt-yard, but he neuer sawe her; yet shee in kindnesse would needes weare a willow garland at his wedding. She lou'd all the Players in the last Queenes time once ouer: She was strook when they acted louers, and forsook some when they plaid murtherers. Shee has nine Spurroyals, and the seruants say she hords old gold; and she herselfe pronounces angerly, that the Farmers eldest sonne, or her Mistres husbands Clark that shall be, that marries her, shall make her a iointure of fourescore pounds a yeer; she tels tales of the seruing-men.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Enough, I know her brother. I shall entreate you onely to salute my Mistres, and take leaue, wee'l part at the staiers.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now Sir, this first part of your will is performed: whats the rest?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: First let me beg your notice for this Gentleman my Brother.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I shall take it as a fauour done to me, though the gentleman hath receiued but an vntimely grace from you, yet my charitable disposition would haue been ready to haue done him freer curtesies as a stranger, then vpon those cold commendations.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Lady, my salutations craue acquaintance and leaue at once.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir I hope you are the master of your owne occasions.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Would I were so. Mistres, for me to praise ouer againe that worth, which all the world, and you your selfe can see.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Its a cold Rome this; Seruant.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Mistres.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What thinke you if I haue a chimney fort out heer?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Mistres another in my place, that were not tyed to beleeue all your actions iust, would apprehend himselfe wrongd: But I, whose vertues are constancy & obedience.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yongloue, make a good fire aboue to warme me after my seruants Exordiums.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I haue heard and seene your affability to bee such, that the seruants you giue wages to may speake.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Tis true, tis true; but they speake toth' purpose.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Mistres your will leades my speeches from the purpose. But as a manâ

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A Simile seruant? This roome was built for honest meaners, that deliuer themselues hastily and plainely, and are gone. Is this a time or place for Exordiums, and Similes, and metaphors? If you haue ought to say, breake intoo't; my answers shall very reasonably meete you.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Mistres I came to see you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thats happily dispacht, the next.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: To take leaue of you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: To be gon?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: you neede not haue dispair'd of that, nor haue vs'd so many circumstances to win me to giue you leaue to performe my command: Is there a third.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Yes, I had a third, had you been apt to heare it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I neuer apter. Fast (good seruant) fast.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Twas to intreat you to heare reason.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Most willingly, haue you brought one can speake it?

sp.speaker: El Lo.
sp.p: Lastly, it is to kindle in that barren heart loue and forgiuenes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You would stay at home?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Yes Ladie.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why you may, and doubtlesly will, when you haue debated that your commander is but your Mistres, a woman, a weake one, wildly ouerborne with passions: but the thing by her commanded, is to see Douers dreadfull cliffe, passing in a pore waterhouse; the dangers of the mercilesse mercilesse twixt that and Callis, fiue long houres saile, with three pore weekes victuals.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: You wrong me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Then to land dumb, vnable to enquire for an English hoast, to remoue from Citty to Cittie, by most chargeable post-horse, like one that rod in quest of his mother tongue.

sp.speaker: El. Lo
sp.p: You wrong me much.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And all these (almost inuincible labours) performed for your mistres to be in danger to forsake her, and to put on new alleagance to some French Lady, who is content to change language with you for laughter, and after your whole yeare spent in tennis and broken speech, to stand to the hazard of being laught at at your returne, and haue tales made on you by the chamber-maids.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: You wrong me much.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Lowder yet.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: You know your least word is of force to make mee seeke out dangers, moue mee not with toies: but in this banishment, I must take leaue to say, you are vniust: was one kisse forc't from you in publike by me so vnpardonable? why all the howers of day and night haue seene vs kisse.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Tis true, and so you satisfied the company that heard me chide.

sp.speaker: El Lo.
sp.p: Your owne eyes were not dearer to you then I?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And so you told vm.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I did, yet no singne of disgrace neede to haue staind your cheeke: you your selfe knew your pure and simple heart to be most vnspotted, and free from the least basenesse.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I did: But if a Maides heart doth but once thinke that shee is suspected, her owne face will write her guiltie.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: But where lay this disgrace? The world that knew vs, knew our resolutions well: And could it bee hop'd that I should giue away my freedome, and venture a perpetuall bondage with one I neuer kist? or could I in strict wisdome take too much loue vpon me, from her that chose me for her husband?

lg.l: Beleeue me; if my wedding smock were on,
Were the gloues bought and giuen, the Licence come,
Were the Rosemary branches dipt, and all
The Hipochrists and cakes eate and drunke off,
Were these two armes incompast with the hands
Of Bachelers, to leade me to the Church;
Were my feete in the dore, were I Iohn, said,
If Iohn should boast a fauour done by me,
I would not wed that yeare: And you I hope,
When you haue spent his yeere commodiously,
In atcheiuing Languages, will at your returne
Acknowledge me more coy of parting with mine eies,
Then such a friend. More talke I hold not now,
If you dare goe!

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I dare you know; First let me kisse.

lg.l: Farewell sweet seruant, your talke perform'd,
On a new ground as a beginning sutor,
I shall be apt to heare you.

sp.speaker: Eld. Lo.
sp.p: Farewell cruell Mistres.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Brother youle hazard the loosing your tide to Grauesend: you haue a long halfe mile by land to Greenewich.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I goe: but brother, what yet vnheard of course to liue, doth your imagination flatter you with? your ordinary meanes are deuourd.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Course? why horse-coursing I thinke. Consume no time in this: I haue no estate to bee mended by meditation: hee that busies himselfe about my fortunes, may properly be said to busie himselfe about nothing.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Yet some course you must take, which for my satisfaction resolue and open: If you will shape none, I must informe you, that that man but perswades himselfe hee meanes to liue, that imagins not the meanes.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Why liue vpon others, as others haue liued vpon mee.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I apprehend not that: you haue fed others, and consequently disposd of vm: and the same measure must you expect from your maintainers, which will be too heauy an alteration for you to beare.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Why ile purse; if that raise mee not, Ile bet at bowling-alleys, or man whores; I would fain liue by others: but Ile liue whilst I am vnhangd, and after the thoughts taken.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I see you are tide to no particular imployment then.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Faith I may choose my course: they say nature brings foorth none but shee prouides for em: Ile trie her liberalitie.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Well, to keepe your feete out of base and dangerous paths, I haue resolued you shall liue as Master of my house. It shall bee your care Sauill to see him fed and clothed, not according to his present estate, but to his birth and former fortunes.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: If it be referd to him, if I be not found in Carnation Iearsie stockins, blew diuels breeches, with three guards downe, and my pocket ith sleeues, ile nere looke you i'th face againe.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: A comlier wear I wusse it is then those dangling slops.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: To keep you ready to doe him all seruice peaceably, and him to command you reasonably, I leaue these further directions in writing, which at your best leisure together open and reade.

div.stage: Enter Yongloue to them with a Iewell.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir my Mr s. commends her loue to you in this token, and these words; It is a Iewell (she saies) which as a fauour from her shee would request you to weare till your yeares trauell be performed: which once expired, she will hastily expect your happy returne.

sp.speaker: El Lo.
sp.p: Returne my seruice with such thanks, as she may imagine the heart of a sodenly ouer-ioyed man would willingly vtter: and you (I hope) I shall with slender arguments perswade to weare this Diamond, that when my Mistres shall through my long absence, and the approch of new sutors, offer to forget mee; you may call your eie downe to your finger, and remember and speake of me: She will heare thee better then those allyed by birth to her; as we see many men much swaied by the groomes of their chambers, not that they haue a greater part of their loue or opinion on them, as on others, but for they know their secrets.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: A my credit I sweare, I thinke twas made for mee: Feare no other sutors.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I shall not neede to teach you how to discredit their beginnings, you know how to take exception at their shirts at washing, or to make the maids sweare they found plasters in their beds.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I know, I know, and doe not you feare the sutors.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Farewell, be mindefull and be happy: the night cals mee.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: The Gods of the winds befriend you Sir: a constant and a liberall louer thou art; more such God send vs.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Let vm not stand still, we haue rid hard.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: A sutor I know by his riding hard, Ile not be seen.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A pretty Hall this, No seruant in't? I would look freshly.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: You haue deliuered your arrand to mee then: ther's no danger in a hansome young fellowe: Ile shew my selfe.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lady may it please you to bestowe vpon a stranger the ordinary grace of salutation: Are you the Ladie of this house?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir, I am worthily proud to be a seruant of hers.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lady I should be as proud to be a seruant of yours, did not my so late acquaintance make me dispaire.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir, it is not so hard to atcheiue, but nature may bring it about.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: For these comfortable words I remaine your glad debtor. Is your Ladie at home?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: She is no stragler Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: May her occasions admit me to speake with her?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: If you come in the way of a Sutor, No.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I know your affable vertue will be moued to perswade her, that a Gentleman benighted and straied offers to be bound to her for a nights lodging.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I will commend this message to her: but if you aime at her bodie, you will be deluded: other weomen the housholds of good carriage and gouernment; vpon any of which if you can cast your affection, they will perhaps bee found as faithfull, and not so coy.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What a skin full of lust is this? I thought I had come awoeing, and I am the courted party. This is right Court fashion: Men, weomen, and all woe; catch that catch may. If this soft hearted woman haue infusde any of her tendernesse into her Lady, there is hope she will be pliant. But who's here?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: God saue you Sir, My Lady lets you know shee desires to be acquainted with your name before she conferre with you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir my name cals me Welford.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sir, you are a gentleman of a good name. I'le trie his wit.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I will vphold it as good as any of my Ancestors had this two hundred yeares Sir.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I knew a worshipfull and a religious gentleman of your name in the Bishopricke of Durham. Call you him Cosen?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am onely allyed to his vertues Sir.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: It is modestly said: I should carry the badge of your Christianity with me to.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Whats that, a Crosse? there's a tester.

sp.speaker: Ro
sp.p: I meane the name which your Godfathers & Godmothers gaue you at the Font.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Tis Harry: but you cannot proceede orderly now in your Catechisme: for you haue told mee who gaue mee that name. Shall beg your names.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Roger.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What roome fill you in this house?

sp.speaker: Ro
sp.p: More roomes then one.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The more the merrier. But may my boldnesse know, why your Lady hath sent you to discipher my name?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Her owne words were these; To know whether you were a formerly denied sutor, disguised in this message: For I can assure you shee delights not in Thalame: Himen and she are at variance, I shall returne with much hast.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And much speede Sir I hope: certainely I am ariued amongst a Nation of new found fooles: on a Land where no Navigator has yet planted wit, If I had foreseene it, I would haue laded my breeches with bels, kniues, copper and glasses to trade with the weomen for their virginities: yet I feare I should haue betraied my selfe to an needlesse charge then: heres the walking night-cap againe.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Sir, my Ladies pleasure is to see you: who hath commanded mee to acknowledge her sorow. that you must take the paines to come vp for so bad entertainement.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I shall obey your Lady that sent it, and acknowledge you that brought it to be your Arts Master.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I am but a Bachiler of Art Sir; aud I haue the mending of all vnder this roofe, from my Lady on her downe bed, to the maide in the pease strawe.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A Cobler Sir?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: No Sir. I inculcate Diuine seruice within these walles,

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But the inhabitants of this house doe often imploy you on errands, without any scruple of conscience.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Yes, I doe take the aire many mornings on foote, three or foure miles for egges: but why moue you that?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To knowe whether it might become your function to bid my man to neglect his horse a little, to attend on mee.

sp.speaker: Ro
sp.p: Most properly Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I pray ye doe so then: and whilst I will attend your Lady. You direct all this house in the true way?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I doe Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And this dore (I hope) conducts to your Lady?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Your vnderstanding is ingenious.

div.stage: Ent. Yong Louelesse & Sauill with a writing.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: By your fauour Sir you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: I shall beate your fauour Sir, crosse me no more; I say they shall come in.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir you forget one, who I am.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Sir I doe not; thou art my brothers Steward, his cast off mill-money, his Kitchen Arethmatick.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir I hope you will not make so little of me.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: I make thee not so little as thou art: for indeed there goes no more to the making of a Steward, but a faire Imprimis, and then a reasonable Item infus'd into him, and the thing is done.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Nay then you stirre my duty, and I must tell you.

sp.speaker: Yo Lo.
sp.p: What wouldst thou tell me, how Hoppes goe, or hold some rotten discourse of sheepe, or when our Lady day fals? Prethee farewell, and entertaine my friends, bee drunke, and burne thy Table-bookes: and my deare sparke of veluet thou and I

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good Sir remember.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: I doe remember thee a foolish fellowe, one that did put his trust in Almanacks, and horse-faiers, and rose by hony and pot-butter. Shall they come in yet?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Nay then I must vnfold your Brothers pleasure, these be the lessons Sir, he left behinde him.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Prethee expound the first.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I leaue to keep my house 300 pounds a yeare; and my Brother to dispose of it.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Marke that my wicked Steward, and I dispose of it.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Whilst hee beares himselfe like a Gentleman, and my credit fals not in him. Marke that my good young Sir, marke that.

sp.speaker: Yong. Lo
sp.p: Nay if it be no more I shall fulfill it: whilst my legs will carry mee ile beare my selfe gentleman-like, but when I am drunke, let them beare mee that can. Forward deare steward.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Next it is my will, that hee bee furnisht (as my brother) with attendance, apparrell, and the obedience of my people.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Steward this is as plaine as your olde minikin breeches. Your wisdome will relent now, will it not? Be mollified orâ you vnderstand mee Sir, proceed.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Next, that my Steward keepe his place, and power, and bound my brothers wildnesse with his care.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Ile heare no more this Apocripha, binde it by it selfe steward.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: This is your Brothers will, and as I take it, he makes no mention of such company as you would draw vnto you. Captaines of Gallifoists, such as in a cleare day haue seene Callis, fellows that haue no more of God, then their oaths comes to: they weare swords to reach fire at a Play, and get there the oyld end of a pipe for their guerdon: then the remnant of your regiment are wealthy Tobacco merchants, that set vp with one ownce, and breake for three; together with a forlorne hope of Poets, and all these looke like Carthusians, things without linnen: Are these fit company for my Masters Brother?

sp.speaker: Yong. Lo.
sp.p:
I will either conuert thee (O thou Pagan steward)
or presently confound thee and thy reckonings, who's there? call in the Gent.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Nay you shall know both who I am, and where I am.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Are you my masters Brother?

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Are you the sage Master Steward, with a face like an olde Ephimerides?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Then God helpe all, I say.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: I, and tis well said my olde peere of France: welcome gentlemen, welcome gentlemen; mine owne deere lads, y'are richly welcome. Know this old Harrygroate.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir I will take your loue.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir you will take my purse.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And studie to continue it.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I doe beleeue you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Your honourable friend and masters brother, hath giuen you to vs for a worthy fellow, and so wee hugge you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Has giuen himselfe into the hands of varlets, not to be caru'd out. Sir are these the peeces?

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: They are the Morrals of the age, the vertues. Men made of Gold.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Of your gold you meane Sir.

sp.speaker: Yong. Lo.
sp.p: This is a man of warre, that cries goe on; and weares his Colours.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: In's nose.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: In the fragrant field. This is a Traueller Sir, knows men and manners, and has plowd vp the Sea so far, till both the poles haue knockt, has seene the Sunne take Coach, and can distinguish the colour of his horses, and their kindes, and had a Flanders Mare leapt there.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Tis much.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I haue seene more Sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
Tis euen enough a conscience; sit downe, and rest you, you are at the end of the world already. Would you had as good a liuing Sir as this Fellowe could
lie you out of has a notable guift in't.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: This ministers the Smoke, and this the Muses.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: And you the clothes, and meate, and money, you haue a goodly generation of vm, praye let vm multiply, your Brothers house is big enough, and to say truth, ha's too much Land, hang it durt.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Why now thou art a louing stinkeard. Fire off thy annotations and thy rent bookes; thou hast a weake braine Sauill, and with the next long Bill thou wilt runne mad. Gentlemen you are once more welcome to three hundred pounds a yeere; wee will bee freely merry, shall we not?

sp.speaker: Captaine.
sp.p: Merry as mirth, and wine my louely Louelesse.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: A serious looke shall be a Iury to excommunicate any man from our company.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: We will haue nobody talke wisely neither.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: What thinke you gentlemen by all this Reuenew in drinke?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I am all for drinke.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I am drie till it be so.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: He that will not crie Amen to this, let him liue sober, seeme wise, and die ath Corum.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: It shall bee so, wee'l haue it all in drinke, let meate and lodging goe, th'are transitory, and shew men meerely mortall: then wee'l haue wenches, euery one his wench, and euery weeke a fresh one: weele keepe no powderd fleshe: all these wee haue by warrant vnder the Title of things necessarie. Heere vpon this place I ground it: the obedience of my people, and all necessaries: Your opinions Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Tis plaine and euident that he meant wenches.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good Sir let me expound it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Heere be as sound men as your selfe Sir.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: This doe I holde to bee the interpretation of it; In this word Necessarie, is concluded all that bee helpes to man: woman was made the first, and therefore heere the chiefest.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Beleeue me tis a learned one, and by these words; The obedience of my people, (you steward being one) are bound to fetch vs wenches.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: He is, he is.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Steward attend vs for instructions.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: But will you keepe no house Sir?

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Nothing but drinke, three hundred pounds in drinke.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: O miserable house, and miserable I that liue to see it. Good Sir keep some meate.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Get vs good whoores, and for your part, Ile bourd you in an Alehouse, you shall haue cheese and onyons.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: What shall become of me, no chimney smoking? Well prodigall, your brother will come home.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Come lads Ile warrant you for wenches, three hundred pounds in drinke.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Lady, her sister Martha, Welford, Yongloue, and others.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir now you see your bad lodging, I must bid you goodnight.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Lady if there be any want, tis in want of you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A little sleepe will ease that complement. Once more good night.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Once more deare Lady, and then all sweet nights.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Deare Sir be short and sweet then.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Shall the morrow proue better to me, shall I hope my sute happier by this nights rest.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is your sute so sickly that rest will helpe it? Pray ye let it rest then till I call for it. Sir as a stranger you haue had all my welcome: but had I knowne your errand ere you came, your passage had been straighter: Sir, good night.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: So faire, and cruell, deare vnkinde goodnight.
Nay Sir you shall stay with me, Ile presse your zeale so far.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: O Lord Sir,

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Doe you loue Tobacco?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Surely I loue it, but it loues not me; yet with your reuerence ile be bold.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Praye light it Sir. How doe you like it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I promise you it is notable stinging geare indeede. It is wet Sir, Lord how it brings downe Reume?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Handle it againe Sir; you haue a warme text of it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Thanks euer premised for it. I promise you it is very powerfull, and by a Trope, spirituall: for certainely it moues in sundrie places.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I, it does so Sir, and me especially to aske Sir, why you weare a night cap.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Assuredly I will speake the truth vnto you; you shall vnderstand Sir, that my head is broken, and by whom; euen by that visible beast the Butler.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The Butler? certainely hee had all his drinke about him when he did it. Strike one of your graue Cassock? The offence Sir?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Reprouing him at Tra-trip Sir, for swearing: you haue the totall surely.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You tould him when his rage was set atilt, and so hee cract your Cannons. I hope hee has not hurt your gentle reading: But shall wee see these Gentleweomen to night?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Haue patience Sir, vntill our fellowe Nicholas bee deceast, that is, a sleepe: for so the word is taken; to sleepe to die, to die to sleepe: a very Figure Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Cannot you cast another for the Gentleweomen?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Not till the man bee in his bed, his graue; his graue, his bed; the very same againe Sir. Our Comick Poet giues the reason sweetly; Plenus rimarum est, he is full of loope-holes, and will discouer to our Patronesse.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Your comment Sir has made me vnderstand you.

div.stage: Enter Maria the Ladies sister, and Yongloue to them with a posset.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sir be addrest, the graces doe salute you with the full bowle of plenty. Is our old enemy entomb'd?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: He's fast?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: And does he snore out supinely with the Poet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, he out-snores the Poet.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Gentlewoman, this curtesie shall binde a stranger to you, euer your seruant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, my Sisters strictnesse makes not vs forget you are a stranger and a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: In sooth Sir were I chang'd into into my Lady, a Gentleman so well indued with parts, should not be lost.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I thanke you Gentlewoman, and rest bound to you. See how this fowle familiar chewes the Cudde: From thee and three and fiftie, good loue deliuer me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Will you sit downe Sir, and take a spoone?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I take it kindely Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It is our best banquet Sir.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Shall we giue thanke,?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I haue to the Gentlewoman already Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good Sir Roger keepe that breath to coole your part o'th posset, you may chance haue a scalding zeale else: and you will needes bee doing, pray tell your twenty to your selfe. Would you could like this Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I would your Sister would like mee as wel Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sure Sir she would not eate you: but banish that imagination; she's onely wedded to herselfe, lies with herselfe, and loues herselfe; and for an other husband then herselfe, he may knock at the gate, but nere come in: bee wise Sir, she's a woman, and a trouble, and has her many faults, the least of which is, she cannot loue you.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: God pardon her, she'l doe worse, would I were worthy his least griefe Mistres Martha.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Now I must ouer-heare her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Faith would thou hadst them all with all my heart: I doe not thinke they would make thee a day older.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir will you put in deeper, tis the sweeter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Wel said old sayings.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: She lookes like one indeed. Gentlewoman you keepe your word, your sweete selfe has made the bottom sweeter.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir I begin a frolick, dare you change Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
My selfe for you, so please you. That smile has turnd my stomacke. This is right the old Embleame of the
Moyle cropping off thistles: Lord what a hunting head shee carries, sure she has been ridden with a Martingale. Now loue deliuer me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Doe I dreame, or doe I wake? surely I know not: am I rub'd off? is this the way of all my mornings prayers? Oh Roger, thou art but grasse, and woman as a flower. Did I for this consume my quarters in meditation, vowes, and wooed her in Heroycall Epistles? Did I expound the Owle, and vndertooke, with labour and expence the recollection of those thousand Peeces, consum'd in Cellers and Tobacco shops of that our honour'd Englishman Ni. Br.? Haue I done this, and am I done thus too? I will end with the Wise-man, and say, He that holds a woman, has an Eele by the tayle.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis so late, and our entertainment (meaning our posset) by this is growne so cold, that 'twere an vnmannerly part longer to hold you from your rest: let what the house has be at your command Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sweet rest be with you Lady; and to you what you desire too.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: It should be some such good thing like your self then.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Heauen keepe mee from that curse, and all my Issue. Good night Antiquitie.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Solamen Miseris socios habuisse doloris: but I alone.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Learned Sir, will you bid my man come to me? and requesting a greater measure of your learning, good night, good Mr Roger.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Good Sir, peace be with you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Adue deare Domine. Halfe a dozen such in a Kingdome would make a man forsweare consession: for who that had but halfe his wits about him would commit the counsell of a serious sin to such a cruell nightcap?
Why how now, shall we haue an Antique?
Whose head do you carry vpon your shoulders, that you jole it so against the post? Is't for your ease? or haue you seene the Sellor? Where are my slippers sir?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Where Sir? haue you got the pot verdugo? haue you seene the horses Sir?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Haue they any meate?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Faith Sir they haue a kinde of wholsome rushes, hay I cannot cal it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And no prouender?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir so I take it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You are merry Sir, and why so?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Faith Sir, heere are no oates to be got, vnlesse youle haue vm in porredge: the people are so mainely giuen to spoonemeate: yonders a cast of Coach-mares of the gentlewomans, the strangest Cattell.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Why they are transpaÌrant sir, you may see through them: and such a house?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come Sir, the truth of your discouery.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir they are in tribes like Iewes: the Kitchen and the Dayrie make one tribe, and haue their faction and their fornication within themselues; the Buttry and the Laundry are an other, and ther's no loue lost; the chambers are intire, and what's done there, is somewhat higher then my knowledge; but this I am sure, betweene these copulations, a stranger is kept vertuous, that is, fasting. But of all this the drinke Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What of that Sir?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Faith Sir I will handle it as the time and your patience will giue me leaue. This drinke, or this cooling Iulip, of which three spoonefuls kils the Calenture, a pinte breeds the cold Palsie.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir you bely the house.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I would I did Sir. But as I am a true man, if twere but one degree colder, nothing but an asses hoofe would hold it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am glad on't Sir: for if it had proued stronger, you had been tongue-tide of these commendations. Light me the candle Sir, Ile heare no more.

div.stage: Enter Yong Louelesse and his Comrades, with wenches, and two Fydlers.

lg.l: Come my braue man of war, trace out thy darling,
And you my learned Councell, set and turne boyes
Kisse till the Cow come home, kisse close, kisse close knaue s.
My moderne Poet, thou shalt kisse in couplets. Ent. with wine.
Strike vp you merry varlets, and leaue your peeping,
This is no pay for Fidlers.
O my deare boy, thy Hercules, thy Captaine
Makes thee his Hilas, his delight, his solace.
Loue thy braue man of war, and let thy bounty
Clap him in Shamois: Let ther be deducted out of our maine potation
Fiue Marks in hatchments to adorne this thigh,
Crampt with this rest of peace, and I will fight
Thy battels.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Thou shalt hau't boy, and sly in Fether, Leade on a march you Michers.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: O my head, O my heart, what a noise and change is heere; would I had been cold ith mouth before this day, and nere haue liud to see this dissolution. Hee that liues within a mile of this place, had as good sleepe in the perpetuall noise of an iron mill. Ther's a dead Sea of drinke ith Sellor, in which goodly vessels lie wract, and in the middle of this deluge appeares the tops of flagons and blacke iacks, like Churches drown ith marshes.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: What art thou come? My sweet Sir Amias welcome to Troy. Come thou shalt kisse my Hellen, and court her in a dance.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good Sir consider.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Shall we consider gentlemen. How say you?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Consider? that were a simple toy ifaith, Consider? whose morrals that? The man that cries Consider, is our foe: let my steele know him.

sp.speaker: Yong. Lo.
sp.p: Stay thy dead doing hand, he must not die yet: prethee be calme my Hector.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Peasant, slaue, thou groome, composde of grudgeings, liue and thanke this Gentleman, thou hadst seene Pluto else. The next consider kils thee.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Let him drinke downe his word againe in a gallon of Sacke.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Tis but a snuffe, make it two gallons, and let him doe it kneeling in repentance.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Nay rather kill me, theres but a lay-man lost. Good Captaine doe your office.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p:
Thou shalt drinke Steward, drinke and dance my Steward. Strike him a horne-pipe sqeakers, take thy striuer,
and pace her till shee stew.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sure Sir I cannot daunce with your Gentlewoman, they are too light for mee, pray breake my head, and let me goe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: He shall dance, he shall dance.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Hee shall daunce, and drinke, and bee drunke and dance, and bee drunke againe, and shall see no meate in a yeere.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: And three quarters.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: And three quarters be it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Who knocks there? let him in.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Some to deliuer me I hope.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Gentlemen, God saue you all, my businesse is to one Mr Louelesse.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: This is the Gentleman you meane; view him, and take his Inuentory, hee's a right one.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: He promises no lesse Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Sir your businesse?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Sir, I should let you know, yet I am loath, yet I am sworne too't, would some other tongue would speake it for mee.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Out with it a Gods name.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: All I desire Sir is, the patience and sufferance of a man, and good Sir be not moou'd more,

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Then a pottle of Sacke will doe, heere's my hand, prethee thy businesse?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Good Sir excuse mee, and whatsoeuer you heare, thinke, must haue beene knowne vnto you, and bee your selfe discreete; and beare it nobly.

sp.speaker: Yong. Lo.
sp.p: Prethee dispatch me.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Your brothers dead Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Thou dost not meane dead drunke?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: No, no, dead and drown'd at sea Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Art sure hee's dead?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Too sure Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo
sp.p: I, but art thou very certainely sure of it?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: As sure Sir as I tell it.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: But art thou sure he came not vp againe?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: He may come vp, but nere to call you brother.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: But art sure he had water enough to drowne him?

sp.speaker: Eld. Lo.
sp.p: Sure Sir he wanted none.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: I would not haue him want, I lou'd him better; heere I forgiue thee: and i'faith bee plaine, how doe I beare it?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Very wisely Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Fill him some wine. Thou dost not see me moou'd, these transitory toyes nere trouble me, hee's in a better place my friend, I know't. Some fellowes would haue cryed now, and haue curst thee, and falne out with their meat, and kept a pudder; but all this helps not, he was too good for vs, and let God keepe him: there's the right vse on't friend. Off with thy drinke, thou hast a spice of sorrow makes thee dry: fill him another, Sauill, your Masters dead, and who am I now Sauill? Nay, let's all beare it well, wipe, Sauill, wipe, teares are but throwne away: we shall haue wenches now, shal we not Sauill? Drinke to my friend Captaine.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: And drinke inumerable.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes forsooth Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: And you'le straine cursie and be drunke a little.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I would be glad, Sir, to doe my weake indeauour.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: You may be brought in time to loue a wench too.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: In time the sturdie Oake Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Some more wine for my friend there.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I shall be drunke anon for my good newes: but I haue a louing brother, that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Heere's to you sir, this is the worst I wish you for your newes: and if I had another elder brother, and say it were his chance to feede more fishes, I should bee still the same you see me now, a poore contented Gentleman. More wine for my friend there, hee's dry againe.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I shall be if I follow this beginning. Well, my deare brother, if I scape this drowning, 'tis your turne next to sinke, you shall ducke twice before I helpe you. Sir I cannot drinke more, 'pray let me haue your pardon.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p:
O Lord sir, 'tis your modestie: more wine, giue him a bigger glasse; hugge him my Captaine, thou shalt
bee my cheefe mourner.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And this my pennon. Sir a ful rouse to you, and to my Lo. of Land heere.

sp.speaker: El. Lou.
sp.p: I feele a buzzing in my braines, pray God they beare this out, and Ile nere trouble them so far againe. Heers to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: To my deare Steward, downe a your knees you infidel, you Pagan; be drunke and penitent.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Forgiue me Sir and ile be any thing.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Then be a Baude: Ile haue thee a braue Baud.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Sir I must take my leaue of you, my busines is so vrgent.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo:
sp.p: Lets haue a bridling cast before you goe. Fils a new stoupe.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I dare not Sir by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Haue you any minde to a wench? I would faine gratifie you for the paines you tooke Sir.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: As little as to the tother.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: If you finde any stirring, doe but say so.

sp.speaker: Eld. Lo.
sp.p: Sir you are too bounteous, when I finde that itching, you shall asswage it Sir before another: this onely, and farewell Sir. Your brother when the storm was most extream, told all about him, he left a will, which lies close behinde a chimney in the matted chamber: and so as well Sir, as you haue made me able, I take my leaue.

sp.speaker: Yong. Lo.
sp.p: Let vs imbrace him all: if you grow drie before you end your businesse, praye take a baite heere, I haue a fresh hogshead for you.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: You shall neither will nor choose sir. My Master is a wonderfull fine Gentleman has a fine state, a very fine state Sir, I am his steward Sir, and his man.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Would you were your owne Sir, as I left you. Well I must cast about, or all sinks.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Farewell Gentleman, Gentleman. Gentleman.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: What would you with me Sir?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Farewell Gentleman.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: O sleepe Sir, sleepe.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Well boies, you see whats falne, lets in and drinke, and giue thankes for it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Let's giue thanks for't.

sp.speaker: Yo Lo.
sp.p: Drunke as I liue.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Drunke as I liue boyes.

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Why now thou art able to discharge thine office, and cast vp a reckoning of some waight; I will bee knighted, for my state wil beare it, 'tis sixteene hundred boies: off with your husks, Ile skin you all in sattin.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: O sweet Louelesse!

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: All in sattin? O sweet Louelesse.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: March in my Noble Compeeres: and this my Countesse shall be led by two: and so proceed we to the will.

div.stage: Enter Moorecraft the vsurer, and Widdow.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: And Widdow, as I say be your owne friend: your husband left you wealthy, I and wise, continue so sweet duck, continue so. Take heede of young smooth varlets, younger brothers, they are wormes that will eate through your bags: they are very lightning, that with a slash or two will melt your money, and neuer singe your purse strings: they are colts, wench, colts, headdy and dangerous, till we take vm vp, and make vm fit for bonds; looke vpon mee, I haue had, and haue yet matter of moment gyrle, matter of moment; you may meete with a worse backe, Ile not commend it.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Nor I neither Sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Yet thus farre by your fauour widdow, 'tis tuffe.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: And therefore not for my dyet, for I loue a tender one.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Sweet widdow leaue your frumps, and bee edified: you know my state, I sell no Perspectiues, Scarses, Gloues, nor Hangers, nor put my trust in Shoo-ties: and where your husband in an age was rising by burnt figs, dreg'd with meale and powdered sugar, saunders and graines, wormeseed and rotten reasons, and such vile tobacco, that made the foot-men mangie; I in a yeere haue put vp hundreds inclose'd, my widdow, those pleasant meadowes, by a forfeit morgage: for which the poore Knight takes alone chamber, owes for his Ale, and dare nor beat his Hostesse: nay moreâ

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Good Sir no more, what ere my husband was, I know what I am, and if you marry mee, you must beare it brauely off Sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Not with the head, sweet widdow.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: No, sweet sir, but with your shoulders: I must haue you dubd, for vnder that I will stoope a feather. My husband was a fellow lou'd to toyle, feede ill, made gaine his exercise, and so grew costiue, which for I was his wife, and gaue way to, and spun mine owne smocks course, and sir, so little; but let that passe. Time, that weares all things out, wore out this husband, who in penitence of such fruitlesse fiue yeeres marriage, left mee great with his wealth, which if you'le bee Ã¡ worthie gossip to, be knighted Sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Now sir, from whom come you? whose man are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir, I come from young Mr Louelesse.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Be silent sir, I haue no money, not a penny for you, hee's sunke, your Master's sunke, a perisht man sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Indeede his brother's sunke Sir, God be with him, a perisht man indeede, and drown'd at Sea.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: How saidst thou, good my friend, his brother drown'd?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Vntimely, Sir, at sea.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: And thy young Master left sole heire?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: And he wants money?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes, and sent me to you; for he is now to be knighted.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Widdow, be wise, there's more land comming, widdow be very wise, and giue thanks for me widdow.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Be you very wise, and bee knighted, and then giue thanks for me Sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: What sayes your Worship to this money?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I say, he may haue money if he please.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: A thousand Sir?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: A thousand Sir, prouided any wise Sir, his land lye for the payment, otherwiseâ

div.stage: Enter Young Louelesse and Comrades to them.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Hee's here himselfe Sir, and can better tell you.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: My notable deare friend, and worthy Mr Louelesse, and now right worshipfull, all ioy and welcome.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Thanks to my deare incloser, Mr Moorecraft; prethee olde Angell gold, salute my family, Ile doe as much for yours; this, and your owne desires, faire Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: And yours Sir, if you meane well; 'tis a hansome Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Sirrha, my brothers dead.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Dead?

sp.speaker: Young Lo.
sp.p: Dead, and by this time souc't for Ember weeke.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Dead?

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Drown'd, drown'd at sea: Man, by the next fresh Conger that comes we shall heare more.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Now by the faith of my body it mooues me much.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: What, wil't thou be an Asse, and weepe for the dead? why I thought nothing but a generall inundation would haue mou'd thee: prethee be quiet, he hath left his land behind him.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: O, ha's he so?

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Yes faith, I thanke him for't, I haue all boy, hast any ready money?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Will you sell Sir?

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: No not outright good Gripe; marry, a morgage, or such a slight securitie.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I haue no money Sir for morgage; If you will sell, and all or none, Ile worke a new Mine for you.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good Sir looke afore you, hee'le worke you out of all else: if you sell all your Land, you haue sold your Countrey, and then you must to sea to seeke your brother, and there lye pickled in a poudering tub, and breake your teeth with biskets and hard beefe that must haue watering Sir: and where's your 300. pounds a yeere in drinke then? If you're tun vp the straights you may, for you haue no calling for drinke there, but with a Cannon, nor no scoring but on your ships sides, and then if you scape with life, and take a fagot boat, and a bottle of Vsquebaugh, come home poore men, like a type of Theames Street stinking of pitch and poore Iohn. I cannot tell Sir, I would be loth to see it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
Steweard, you are an Asse, a measel'd mungrell, and were it not againe the peace of my soueraigne friend heere, I would breake your forecasting coxcombe, dogge I would, euen with thy staffe of office there, thy pen and Inkhorne. Noble boy, the god of gold here has sed thee well, take mony for thy durt: hark & beleeue, thou art cold of constitution, thy seat vnhealthful, sell & be wise; we are three that will adorne thee,
and liue according to thine owne heart childe: mirth shall be onely ours, and onely ours shal be the blacke eyde beauties of the time. Money makes men eternall.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Doe what you will, 'tis the noblest course, then you may liue without the charge of people, onely wee foure will make a family, I and an age that shall beget new Annals, in which Ile write thy life my sonne of pleasure, equall with Nero or Caligula.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: What meane they Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Two roring boyes of Rome that made all split.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Come Sir, what dare you giue?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: You will not sell Sir?

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Who told you so Sir?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good Sir haue a care.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Peace, or Ile tacke your tongue vp to your roofe. What money? speake.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Sixe thousand pound Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Take it, h'as ouerbidden by the Sunne: binde him to his bargaine quickly.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Come, strike mee lucke with earnest, and draw the writings.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: There's a Gods penny for thee.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir, for my old Masters sake let my Farme be excepted, if I become his tenant I am vndone, my children beggers, and my wife God knowes what: consider me deare Sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Ile haue all in or none.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: All in, all in: dispatch the writings.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Goe, thou art a pretty forehanded fellow, would thou wert wiser.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Now doe I sensibly begin to feele my selfe a rascall: would I could teach a Schoole, or begge, or lye well, I am vtterly vndone; now he that taught thee to deceiue and cousen, take thee to his mercy: so be it.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Come widdow, come, neuer stand vpon a knighthood, 'tis a meere paper honour, and not proofe enough for a Sergeant. Come, come, Ile make theeâ

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: To answere in short, 'tis this Sir, No knight, no widow: if you make mee any thing, it must be a Lady; and so I take my leaue.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Farewell sweet widdow, and thinke of it.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Sir I do more then thinke of it, it makes me dreame sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Shee's rich and sober, if this itch were from her: and say I bee at charge to pay the Footmen, and the Trumpett, I and the Horsmen too, and be a Knight, and she refuse me then: then am I hoyst into the Subsidy, and so by consequence should proue a Coxcombe: Ile haue a care of that. Sixe thousand pound, and then the Land is mine, there's some refreshing yet.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: IF he but follow mee, as all my hopes tels me hee's man enough, vp goes my rest, and I know I shall draw him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: This is the strangest pamperd peece of flesh towards fiftie, that euer frailty cop't withall, what a trim Lenuoy heere she has put vpon me: these woemen are a proud kinde of cattell, and loue this whorson doing so directly, that they wil not sticke to make their very skinnes Bawdes to their flesh. Here's dogskin and storax sufficient to kill a Hauke: what to do with it, beside nayling it vp amongst Irish heads of Teere, to shew the mightines of her palme, I know not: there she is, I must enter into Dialogue. Lady you haue lost your gloue.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Not Sir if you haue found it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: It was my meaning Lady to restore it.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: 'Twill be vnciuell in me to take backe a fauour, Fortune hath so well bestowed Sir, 'pray weare it for me.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I had rather weare a Bell. But harke you Mistrisse, What hidden vertue is there in this gloue, that you would haue me weare it? Is't good aganst sore eyes, or wil it charme the toothake? Or these red tops, beeing steept in white wine soluble, wil't kill the itch? or h'as it so conceald a prouidence to keepe my hand from bonds? If it haue none of these, and prooue no more but a bare gloue of halfe a crowne a payre, twill bee but halfe a courtesie, I weare two alwaies: faith let's draw cuts, one will doe me no pleasure.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p:
The tendernesse of his yeeres keepes him as yet in ignorance:
hee's a well moulded fellow, and I wonder his bloud should stirre no higher; but tis his want of company: I must grow neerer to him.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: God saue you both.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: And pardon you Sir: this is somewhat rude, how came you hither?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Why through the dores, they are open.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What are you? and what businesse haue you here?

sp.speaker: El Lo.
sp.p: More I beleeue then you haue.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Who would this fellow speake with? Art thou sober?

sp.speaker: Eld. Lo
sp.p: Yes, I come not here to sleepe.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Prethee what art thou?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: As much (gay man) as thou art, I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Art thou no more?

sp.speaker: El Lo.
sp.p: Yes, more then thou dar'st be, a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Thou dost not come to quarrell?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: No, not with weomen; I come to speake here with a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Why I am one.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: But not with one so gentle.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: This is a fine fellow.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Sir I am not fine yet, I am but new come ouer, direct mee with your ticket to your Taylor, and then I shall bee fine Sir. Lady, if there be a better of your sex within this house, say I would see her.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Why am not I good enough for you Sir?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Your way you'le be too good, 'pray end my busines. This is another Suter: O frayle woman.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: This fellow with his bluntnes hopes to doe more then the long suites of a thousand could: though he be sowre hee's quicke I must not trust him. Sir, this Lady is not to speake with you, she is more serious: you smell as if you were new ralkt; goe and be hansome, and then you may sit with her Seruingmen.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: What are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Guesse by my outside.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Then I take you Sir for some new silken thing wean'd from the countrey, that shall (when you come to keepe good company) be beaten into better manners. 'Pray good proud Gentlewoman helpe me to your Mistres.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: How many liues hast thou, that thou talk'st thus rudely?

sp.speaker: El Lo.
sp.p: But one, I am neither cat nor woman.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And will that one life Sir maintaine you euer in such bold sawcinesse?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Yes amongst a nation of such men as you are, and be no worse for wearing Shall I speake with this Lady?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: No by my troth shall not you.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I must stay here then.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: That you shall not neyther.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Good fine thing tell me why.

lg.l: Good angry thing Ile tell you:
This is no place for such companions,
Such lousie Gentlemen shall finde their businesse
Better i'th the Suburbs; there your strong pitch persume,
Mingled with lees of Ale, shall reeke in fashion:
This is no Thames street Sir.
This Gentleman informes you truly:
Prethee be satisfied, and seeke the Suburbs,
Good Captaine, or whateuer title else,
The warlike Eeleboats haue bestow'd vpon thee,
Goe and reform thy selfe: prethee be sweeter,
And know my Lady speakes with no such swabbers.
You cannot talke me out with your tradition
Of wit you picke from plaies, goe too, I haue found yee:
And for you, tender Sir, whose gentle bloud
Runnes in your nose, and makes you snuffe at all
But three pil'd people, I doe let you know,
He that be got your worships sattin sute,
Can make no men Sir: I will see this Lady,
And with the reuerence of your silkenship,
In these old Ornaments.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You will not sure.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Sure Sir I shall.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: You would be beaten out.

lg.l: Indeed I would not, or if I would beaten,
Pray who shall beat me? this good Gentleman
Lookes as he were o'th peace.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir you shall see that: will you get you out?

lg.l: Yes, that, that shall correct your boyes tongue,
Dare you fight? I will stay here still.
O their things are out, helpe, helpe for Gods sake,
Maddam; Iesus they foyne at one another,
Maddam, why who is within there? Enter Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Who breedes this rudenes?

lg.l: This vnciuill fellow:
He sayes he comes from sea, where I beleeue
H'as purg'd away his manners.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What of him?

lg.l: Why he will rudely, without once God blesse you,
Presse to your priuacies, and no deniall
Must stand betwixt your person and his businesse;
I let goe his ill language.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir, haue you businesse with me?

lg.l: Maddame some I haue,
But not so serious to pawne my life for't:
If you keepe this quarter, and maintaine about you
Such Knights o'th Sun as this is, to defie
Men of imployment to yee, you may liue,
But in what some?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray stay Sir, who h'as wrong'd you?

lg.l: Wrong me he cannot, though vnciuilly
He flung his wilde words at me: But to you
I thinke he did no honour, to deny
The haste I come withall, a passage to you,
Though I seeme course.
Excuse me, gentle sir, twas from my knowledge,
And shall haue no protection. And to you Sir,
You haue shewed more heat then wit, and from your selfe
Haue borrowed power, I neuer gaue you here,
To doe these wilde vnmanly things: my house
Is no blinde streete to swagger in: and my fauours
Not doting yet on your vnknowne deserts
So farre, that I should make you Master of my businesse:
My credit yet, stands fayrer with the people
Then to be tryed with swords: And they that come
To doe me seruice, must not thinke to winne me
With hazard of a murther: If your loue
Consist in fury, carry it to the Campe,
And there in honour of some common mistres,
Shorten your youth. I pray be better temperd,
And giue me leaue a while Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You must haue it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now Sir, your businesse?

lg.l: First I thanke you for schooling this young fellow,
Whom his owne follies, which is prone inough
Daily to fall into, if you but frowne,
Shall leuell him away to his repentance:
Next I should rayle at you, but you are a woman,
And anger lost vpon you.
Why at me Sir?
I neuer did you wrong, for to my knowlege
This is the first sight of you.
You haue done that,
I must confesse I haue the least curse in,
Because the least acquaintance: But there be
(If there be honour in the mindes of men)
Thousands, when they shall know what I deliuer,
(As all good men must share in't) will to shame
Blast your blacke memory.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How is this good Sir?

lg.l: Tis that, that if you haue a soule will choake it:
Y'aue kild a Gentleman:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I kild a Gentleman?

lg.l: You and your crueltie haue kild him woman;
And such a man (let me be angry in't)
Whose least worth waighed aboue all weomens vertues
That are, I spare you all to come too: guesse him now.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I am so innocent I cannot Sir.

lg.l: Repent you meane: you are a perfect woman,
And as the first was, made for mans vndoing.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir you haue mist your way, I am not she.

lg.l: Would he had mist his way too, though hee had
Wandered farther then weomen are ill spoken of,
So he had mist this misery, you Lady.

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: How doe you doe Sir?

lg.l: Well inough I hope,
While I can keepe my selfe from such temptations.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray leape into this matter, whither would yee?

lg.l: You had a Seruant that your peeuishnes
Inioyned to trauell.
Such a one I haue
Still, and should be grieued 'twere otherwise.
Then haue your asking, and be grieu'd, hee's dead;
How you will answere for his worth I know not,
But this I am sure, eyther he, or you, or both
Were starke mad, else he might haue liu'd
To haue giuen a stronger testimony toth' world
Of what he might haue beene. He was a man
I knew but in his euening: ten Sunnes after,
Forc't by a tyrant storme our beaten barke
Bulg'd vnder vs; in which sad parting blow,
He cal'd vpon his Saint, but not for life,
On you vnhappy woman; and whilst all
Sought to preserue their soules, he desperately
Imbrac't a waue, crying to all that see it,
If any liue, goe to my Fate, that forc't me
To this vntimely end, and make her happy:
His name was Louelesse: And I scap't the storme.
And now you haue my businesse.
Tis too much.
Would I had beene that storme, he had not perisht.
If you'le raile now I will forgiue you Sir,
Or if you'le call in more, if any more
Come from this ruine, I shall iustly suffer
What they can say: I doe confesse my selfe
A guilty cause in this. I would say more,
But griefe is growne to great to be deliuered.
I like this well: these weomen are strange things.
Tis somewhat of the latest now to weepe,
You should haue wept when he was going from you,
And chain'd him with those teares at home.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Would you had told me then so, these two armes had beene his Sea.

sp.speaker: Eld. Lo.
sp.p: Trust mee you mooue me much: but say he liued, these were forgotten things againe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I, say you so? Sure I should know that voyce: this is knauery. Ile fit you for it: Were he liuing sir, I would perswade you to be charitable, I, and confesse we are not all so ill as your opinion holds vs. O my friend, what penance shall I pull vpon my fault, vpon my most vnworthy selfe for this?

lg.l: Leaue to loue others, 'twas some jealousie
That turn'd him desperate.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ile be with you straight: are you wrung there?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: This works amaine vpon her.

lg.l: I doc confesse there is a Gentleman
H'as borne me long good will.

sp.speaker: E. Lo.
sp.p: I doe not like that.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And vowed a thousand seruices to me; to me, regardlesse of him: But since Fate, that no power can withstand, h'as taken from me my first and best Loue, and to weepe away my youth is a meere folly: I will shew you what I determine sir: you shall know all: Call Mr. Welford there: That Gentleman I meane to make the modell of my Fortunes, and in his chaste imbraces keepe aliue the memory of my lost louely Louelesse: hee is somewhat like him too.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Then you can Loue?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes certaine sir.

lg.l: Though it please you to thinke me hard and cruell,
I hope I shall perswade you otherwise.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I haue made my selfe a fine foole.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Would you haue spoke with me Maddame?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes Mr. Welford, and I aske your pardon before this gentleman, for being froward: This kisse, and henceforth more affection.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: So, 'tis better I were drown'd indeed.

lg.l: This is a sudden passion, God hold it.
This fellow out of his feare sure ha's
Perswaded her, Ile giue him a new suit on't.
A parting kisse: and good Sir let me pray you
To waite me in the Gallerie.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am in another world. Maddame where you please.

sp.speaker: El. Lo
sp.p: I will to Sea, an't shal go hard but Ile be drown'd indeed.

lg.l: Now Sir you see I am no such hard creature,
But time may winne me.

sp.speaker: El Lo.
sp.p: You haue forgot your lost Loue,

sp.speaker: La
sp.p:
Alas Sir, what would you haue me doe? I cannot call him backe againe with sorrow; Ile loue this man as deerely, and beshrow
me, Ile keepe him farre inough from sea: and twas told me, now I remember me, by an old wise woman, that my first Loue should be drown'd: and see Tis come about.

sp.speaker: El Lo.
sp.p: I would she had told you your second should be hang'd to, and let that Come about: but this is very strange.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Faith Sir, consider all, and then I know you'le bee of my minde: if weeping would redeeme him, I would weepe still.

lg.l: But say that I were Louelesse,
And scap't the storme, how would you answere this?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why for that Gentleman I would leaue all the world.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: This young thing too?

lg.l: That young thing too,
Or any young thing else: why I would lose my stare.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Why then he liues still, I am he, your Louelesse.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A as I knew it Sir, and for that purpose prepar'd this Pageant: get you to your taske. And leaue these Players tricks, or I shal leaue you, indeede I shall. Trauell, or know me not.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Will you then marry?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I will not promise, take your choyse. Farewell.

lg.l: There is no other Purgatory but a woman.
I must doe something.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Mistres I am bold.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You are indeed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You haue so ouerioyed me Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Take heed you surfet not, pray fast and welcome.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By this light you loue me extremely.

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: By this, and tomorrowes light, I care not for you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come, come, you cannot hide it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Indeed I can, there you shall neuer finde it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I like this mirth well Lady

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You shall haue more on't.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I must kisse you.

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: No fir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Indeed I must.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What must be, must be; Ile take my leaue, you haue your parting blow: I pray commend me to those few friends you haue, that sent you hither, and tell them, when you trauell next, 'twere fit you brought lesse brauery with you, and more wit, you'le neuer get a wise else.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes faith. Wil you eat sir? your horses wil be ready straight, you shall haue a napkin laid in the buttery for yee.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Do not you loue me then?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes, for that face.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: It is a good one Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes, if it were not warpt, the fire in time may mend it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Me thinks yours is none of the best Lady.

lg.l: No by my troth Sir: yet o'my conscience,
You could make shift with it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come, 'pray no more of this.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I will not: Fare you well. Ho, who's within there? bring out the Gentlemans horses, hee's in haste; and set some cold meate on the table.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I haue too much of that, I thanke you Lady: take your Chamber when you please, there goes a black one with you Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Farewell young man.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You haue made me one. Farewell: and may the curse of a great house fall vpon thee, I meane the Butler. The Diuell and all his works are in these women: would all of my sexe were of my minde, I would make vm a new Lent, and a long one, that flesh might be in more reuerence with them.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I am sorry Mr. Welford.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: So am I, that you are here.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: How do's my Lady vse you?

sp.speaker: Wel
sp.p: As I would vse you, scuruily.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I should haue beene more kinde Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I should haue beene vndone then. 'Pray leaue mee, and looke to your sweet meats: harke, your Lady calls.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sir I shall borrow so much time without offending.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Y'are nothing but offence: for Gods loue leaue me.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Tis strange my Lady should be such a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: To send you to mee. 'Pray goe stitch, good doe, y'are more trouble to me then a Terme.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I doe not know how my good will, if I said loue I lyed not, should any way deserue this.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A thousand waies, a thousand waies: sweet creature let me depart in peace.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: What creature Sir? I hope I am a woman.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A hundred I thinke by your noyse.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Since you are angry sir, I am bold to tell you, that I am a woman, and a ribbe.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Of a roasted horse.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Conster me that.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
A Dogge can doe it better. Farewell Countesse, and commend me to your Lady: tell her shee's proud, and scuruy; and
so I commit you both to your tempter.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Welford.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Auoide olde Satanus: Goe daube your ruines, your face lookes fowler then a storme: the footeman staies you in the Lobby Ladie.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: If you were a Gentleman I should know it by your gentle conditions? are these fit words to giue a gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: As fit as they were made for yee: Sirrah, my horses. Farewell old Adage, keepe your nose warme, the Reume will make it horne else.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: The blessings of a prodigall young heire be thy companions Welforde, Marry come vp my gentleman, are your gummes growne so tender they cannot bite? A skittish Filly will be your fortune Welford, and faire enough for such a packsaddle. And I doubt not, (if my aime hold) to see her made to amable to your hand.

div.stage: Enter Yo. Louelesse and Comrades, Moorcraft, Widow, Sauil, and therest.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Saue thy braue shoulder, my young puissant Knight, and may thy back-sword bite them to the bone, that loue thee not: thou art an errant man, goe on. The circumcisde shall fall by thee Let land and labour fill the man that tils, thy sword must bee thy plough, and Ioue it speede. Mecha shall sweate, and Mahomet shall fall, and thy deere name fill vp his monument.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: It shall Captaine, I meane to be a worthy.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: One worthy is too little, thou shalt be all.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Captaine I shall deserue some of your loue too.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Thou shalt haue heart and hand to noble Mooreraft, if thou wilt lend me money. I am a man of Garrison, be rulde, and open to me those infernall gates, whence none of thy euill angels passe againe, and I will stile thee Noble; nay Don Diego, Ile woe thy Infanta for thee, and my Knight shall feast her with high meats, and make her apt.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Pardon me Captaine, y'are beside my meaning.

lg.l: No Mr. Moorecraft, t'is the Captaines meaning
I should prepare her for yee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Or prouoke her. Speake my moderne man, I say prouoke her.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Captaine I say so too, or stir her to it. So saies the Criticks.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p:
But howsoeuer you expound it Sir, she's very welcome,
and this shall serue for witnesse. And widdow, since y'are come so happily, you shall deliuer vp the keys, and free possession of this house; whilst I stand by to ratifie.

lg.l: I had rather giue it back againe beleeue me,
'Tis a misery to say you had it. Take heede.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: 'Tis past that widowe, come, sit downe; some wine there: there is a scuruy banquet if we had it. All this faire house is yours Sir. Sauill.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Are your keys ready, I must ease your burden.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I am ready Sir to be vndone, when you shall call me to't.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Come come, thou shalt liue better.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I shall haue lesse to doe, thats all, ther's halfe a dozen of my friends ith fields, sunning against a banke, with halfe a breech among vm, I shall bee with vm shortly. The care and continuall vexation of being rich eate vp this rascall. What shall become of my poore familie? they are no sheepe, and they must keepe themselues.

lg.l: Drinke Mr. Moorecraft, praye be merry all:
Nay and you willl not drinke ther's no society.
Captaine speake lowd, and drinke: widdow a word.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Expound her throughly Knight. Here God a gold, here's to thy faire possessions: Bee a Barron, and a bolde one: leaue off your tickling of young heires like trouts, and, let thy chimneys smoke. Feede men of war, liue and bee honest, and be saued yet.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I thanke you worthy Captain for your counsell. You keep your chimneys smoking there, your nostrels, and when you can, you feede a man of war: this makes not you a Barron, but a bare-one: and how or when you shall be saued, let the clarke o'th company (you haue commanded) haue a iust care of.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.p: The man is much is much moued. Be not angry Sir, but as the Poet sings; Let your displeasure be a short furie, and goe out. You haue spoke home, and bitterly, to me Sir? Captain take truce the Miser is a tart and a witty whorson.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Poet you faine perdie, the wit-of this man lies in his fingers ends, he must tell al: his tongue fils but his mouth like a neatstongue, and onely serues to lick his hungry chaps after a purchase: his braines and brimstone are the Diuels diet to a fat vserers head. To her Knight, to her: clap her abourd and stow her. Wheres the braue Steward?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Heres your poore friend, and Sauil Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A way, th'art rich in ornaments of nature. First in thy face, thou hast a serious face, a betting, bargaining, and sauing face, a rich face, pawne it to the Vsurer; a face to kindle the compassion of the most ignorant and frozen Iustice.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: 'Tis such, I dare not shew it shortly sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: By blithe and bonny Steward: Master Moorecraft, Drinke to this man of reckoning.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Heere's e'ne to him.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The Diuell guide it downward: would there were in't an acre of the great broome field he bought, to sweepe your durty conscience, or to choake ye, 'tis all one to me Vsurer.

sp.speaker: Yong. Lo.
sp.p: Consider what I told you, you are young, vnapt for worldly busines: Is it fit one of such tendernes, so delicate, so contrary to things of care, should stirre and breake her better meditations, in the bare brokage of a brace of Angels? or a new kirtell, though it be of satten? Eate by the hope of surfets, and lie downe onely in expectation of a morrow that may vndoe some easie harted foole, or reach a widowes curses? Let out money, whose vse returnes the principall? and get out of these troubles, a consuming heire: For such a one must follow necessary, you shall die hated, if not old and miserable; and that possest wealth that you got with pining, liue to see tumbled to anothers hands, that is no more akin to you, then you to his cosenage.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Sir you speake well, would God that charity had first begunne here.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Tis yet time. Be merry, me thinkes you want wine there, ther's more i'th house: Captaine, where rests the health?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: It shall goe round boy?

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo
sp.p:
Say you can suffer this, because the end points at much profit, can you so farre bow below your blood, below your too much bewty, to be a partner of this fellowes bed, and lie with his diseases? If you can, I will not presse you further: yet looke vpon him: ther's nothing in that hide-bound Vsurer; that man of mat, that all decai'd, but aches: for you to loue, vnlesse his perisht lungs his drie cough, or his scuruy. This is truth, and so farre I dare speak yet: he has yet past cure of Phisicke, spaw, or any diet, a primatiue pox in his bones; and a' my knowledge hee has beene tenne times rowell'd: ye may loue him; he had a bastard, his owne toward issue,
whipt, and then cropt for washing out the roses, in three farthings to make vm pence.

sp.speaker: Wi
sp.p: I doe not like these Morrals.

sp.speaker: Yo Lo.
sp.p: You must not like him then.

sp.speaker: Eld Lo.
sp.p: By your leaue Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: By my troth Sir you are welcome, welcome faith: Lord what a stranger you are growne; pray know this Gentlewoman, and if you please these friends here: We are merry, you see the worst on's: your house has been kept warme Sir:

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I am glad to heare it brother, pray God you are wise too.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Moorecraft know my elder brother, and Captaine doe your complement. Sauil, I dare swere is glad at heart to see you: Lord, we heard Sir you were droun'd at Sea, and see how luckely things come about?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: This money must be paid againe Sir?

sp.speaker: Yo L. o
sp.p: No Sir, pray keepe the sale, t'wil make good Taylers measures? I am well I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: By my troth the Gentleman has stew'd him in his owne sauce, I shal loue him fort.

sp.speaker: Sa
sp.p: I know not where I am, I am so glad: your worship is the welcom'st man aliue; vpon my knees I bid you welcome home: here has beene such a hurry, such a din, such dismall drinking, swearing, and whoring, 'thas almost made me mad: We hauc al hu'd in a continuall Turneball streete; Sir blest be Heauen, that sent you safe againe. Now shall I eate and goe to bed againe.

sp.speaker: El Lo
sp.p: Brother dismisse these people.

sp.speaker: Young L.
sp.p: Captaine be gone a while, meet me at my old Randeuouse in the euening, take your small Poet with you Mr. Moorecraft, you were best goe prattle with your learned Counsell, I shall preserue your money. I was cosen'd when time was, we are quit Sir.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Better and better still:

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
