sp.p: What is this fellow brother?

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: The thirsty Vsurer that supt my Land off:

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: What does he tarry for?

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Sir to b Land-lord of your house and state: I was hold to make a little sale Sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Am I ouer-reacht? if there be law, Ile hamper yee.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p:
Prethee bee gone, and raile at home, thou art so base a foole I cannot laugh at thee: Sirrha, this comes of cousening, home and spare, care reddish til you raise your summes againe. If you stir
farre in this, Ile haue you whipt, your eares nayl'd for intelligencing, o'th pillory, and your goods forfeit: you are a stale Cousener, leaue my house: no more.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: A poxe vpon your house. Come Widdow, I shall yet hamper this young gamester.

sp.speaker: Wi
sp.p: Good twelue i'th hundred keepe your way, I am not for your dyet: marry in your owne Tribe Iow, and get a Brokes.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Tis well said widdow: will you jogge on Sir?

lg.l: Yes, I will goe, but 'tis no matter whither:
But when I trust a wilde foole, and a woman,
May I lend gratis, and build Hospitals.

sp.speaker: Yo Lo.
sp.p: Nay good sir make all euen, here's a widdow wants your good word for me: shee's rich, and may renue me & my Fortunes.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I am glad you looke before you. Gentlewoman, here is a poore distressed younger brother.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: You doe him wrong Sir, hee's a Knight.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I aske your mercy: yet 'tis no matter, his Knighthood is no inheritance I take it: whatsoeuer he is, hee's your seruant, or would bee Lady. Faith bee not mercilesse, but make a man; hees young and hansome, though he be my brother, and his obseruances may deserue your loue: hee shall not fall for meanes.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Sir, you speake like a worthy brother: and so much I doe cerdit your faire language, that I shall loue your brother: and so loue him, but I shall blush to say more.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Stop her mouth. I hope you shall not liue to know that houre when this shall be repented. Now brother I should chide, but Ile giue no distaste to your faire Mistrisse, I wil instruct her in't, and she shall doo't: you haue bin wild, and ignorant, 'pray mend it.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Sir euery day now spring comes on.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: To you, good Mr. Sauill, and your Office, thus much I haue to say: Y'are from my Steward become, first your owne Drunkard, then his Bawde: they say y'are excellent growne in both, and perfect: giue me your keyes Sir Sauill.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good Sir consider who you left me too.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p:
I left you as a curbe for, not to prouoke my brothers follies: Where's the best drinke now? come, tell me Sauill: where's the soundest whores? Ye old he Goat, ye dry'd Ape, ye lame stallion, must you be leading in my house your whores, like Fayries dance their night rounds, without feare eyther of King or Constable,
within my walles? Are all my Hangings safe? my sheepe vnsold yet? I hope my Plate is currant, I ha' too much on't. What say you to 300. ponnds in drinke now?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good Sir forgiue me, and but heare me speake.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Me thinks thou shouldst be drunke still, and not speak, 'tis the more pardonable.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I will sir, if you will haue it so.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I thanke ye; yes e'ne pursue it Sir: doe you heare? get a whore soone for your recreation: goe loose out Captaine Brokenbreech your fellow, aud quarrell, if you dare: I shall deliuer these keyes to one shall haue more honesty, though not so much fine wit Sir. Yee may walke and gather Cresses sir to coole your liuer; there's something for you to begin a dyet, you'le haue the poxe else. Speed you well, Sir Sauill: you may eate at my house to preserue life; but keepe no fornications in the stables.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Now must I hang my selfe, my friends will looke for't. Eating and sleeping, I doe despise you both now: I will runne mad first, and if that get not pitty, Ile drowne my selfe, to a most dismall ditty. Exit Sauill.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p:
A Lasse poore Gentlewoman, to what a misery hath age brought thee to? to what scuruy Fortune? thou that hast beene a companion for Noble men, & at the worst of those times for Gentlemen: now like a broken Seruingman, must begge for fauour to those that would haue crawl'd like Pilgrims to my chamber, but for an apperition of me: you that bee comming on, make much of fifteene, and so till fiue and twenty: vse your time with reuerence, that your profit may arise: it will not tarry with you Ecce signum: here was a face, but time that like a sunset eates our youth, plague of his Iron teeth, and draw vm for't, h'as been a little bolder here then welcome: and now to say the truth I am fit for no man. Old men i'th house, of fiftie, call me Granam; and when they are drunke, e'ene then, when Ione and my Lady are all one, not one will doe me reason. My little Leuite hath forsaken
me, his siluer sound of Cytterne quite abolish't, his dolefull hymmes vnder my chamber window, digested into tedious learning: well foole, you leap't a Haddock when you left him: hee's a cleane man, & a good Edifier, & twenty nobles is his state de Claro, besides his pigges in posse. To this good Homilist I haue beene euer stubborne, which God forgiue me for, and mend my manners: and Loue, if euer thou hadst care of fortie, of such a peece of lape ground, heare my prayer, and fire his zeale so farre forth that my faults, in this renued impression of my loue, may shew corrected to our gentle Reader. Enter Roger.

See how neglectingly he passes by me: with what an Equipage Canonicall, as though he had broke the heart of Bellarmine, or added some thing to the singing Brethren. Tis scorne, I know it, and deserue it. Mr. Rogor.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Faire Gentlewoman, my name is Roger.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Then gentle Roger.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Vngentle Abigall.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Why Mr. Reger will you set your wit to a weak womans.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: You are weake indeed: for so the Poet sings.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I doe confesse my weaknesse sweet Sir Roger.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Good my Ladies Gentlewoman, or my good Ladies Gentlewoman (this trope is lost to you now) leaue your prating, you haue a season of your first Mother in yee: and surely had the diuel beene in loue, he had beene abused too, goe Dalida; you make men fooles, and weare figge breeches.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Well, well, hard hearted man; dilate vpon the weake infirmities of women: these are fit texts: but once there was a time, would I had neuer seene those eies, those eies, those orient eies.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I they were pearles once with you.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sauing your reuerence Sir, so they are still.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I doe beseech you leaue your cogging, what they ate, they are, they serue me without Spectacles I thanke vm,

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O will you kill me?

lg.l: I doe not thinke I can,
Y'are like a Coppy-hold with nine liues in't.
You were wont to beare a Christian feare about you:
For your owne Worships sake.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p:
I was a Christian foole then: Doe you remember what a dance you led me? how I grew quaum'd in loue, and was a dunce?
could expound but once a quarter, & then was out too: and then at prayers once (out of the stinking stir you put me in) I praid for mine owne royall issue. You doe remember all this?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O be as then you were.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I thanke you for it; surely I wil be wiser Abigall: and as the Ethnick Poet sings, I wil not loose my oile and labour too. Y'are for the worshipfull I take it Abigall.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O take it so, and then I am for thee.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I like these teares well, and this humbling also, they are Symptomes of contrition, as a Father saith. If I should fall into my fit againe, would you not shake me into a quotidian Coxcombe? Would you not vse me scuruily againe, and giue me possets with purging comsets in't? I tel thee Gentlewoman, thou hast been harder to me then a long chapter with a pedigree.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O Curate cure me: I will loue thee better, dearer, longer, I wil doe anything, betray the secrets of the maine household to thy reformation. My Ladie shall looke louely on thy learning; and when true time shal point thee for a Parson, I will ennuert thy egs to penny custards, and thy tythe goose shall grase and multiplie.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I am mollified: as wel shal testifie this faithful kisse: and haue a great care Mistres, Abigall, how you depresse the spirit any more with your rebukes and mockes: for certainely the edge of such a folly cuts it selfe.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O sir you haue pierst me thorow. Heere I vow a recantation to those malitious faults I euer did against you. Neuer more will I despise your learning neuer more pin cardes and cunny tailes vpon your Cassock, neuer againe reproach your reuerend night-cap, and cal it by the mangie name of murrin, neuer your reuerend person more, and say, you looke like one of Baals Priests a hanging; neuer againe, when you say grace, laugh at you, nor put you out at prayers: neuer crampe you more with the great Booke of Martyrs; nor when you ride, get sope and thistles for you. No my Roger, these faults shall be corrected and amended, as by the tenor of my teares appeares.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Now cannot I hold if I should bee hang'd, I must crie to. Come to thine own beloued, & doe euen what thou wilt with me, sweet, sweet, Abi. I am thine own for euer: heer's my hand, when Ro. proues a recreant, hang him i'th Bel-ropes. Ent. La. and Mar.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why how now Mr. Roger, no prayers downe with you to night? did you heare the bell ring? You are courting, your flock shall fat well for it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I humblie aske your pardon: Ile clap vp Praiers (but staie a little) and be with you againe.

lg.l: How dare you being so vnworthie a Fellow,
Presume to come to moue me anie more?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What ailes the fellow.

sp.speaker: Eld. Lo.
sp.p: The fellow comes to laugh at you. I tell you Lady, I would not for your Land, be such a Coxecome, such a whining Asse, as you decreed me for when I was last heere.

lg.l: I ioy to heare you are wise Sir, tis a rare Iewell
In an elder Brother: praye be wiser yet.
Me thinks I am very wise: I doe not come a woeing;
Indeed Ile moue no more loue to your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What make you heere then?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Onely to see you, and be merry Ladie: thats all my businesse. Faith lets be verie merrie. Wher's little Roger? he's a good fellow: an hower or two well spent in wholsome mirth is worth a thousand of these puling passions. Tis an ill world for Louers.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: They were neuer fewer.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I thanke God ther's one lesse for me Ladie.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You were neuer any Sir.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Till now; and now, I am the prettiest fellow.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You talke like a Taylor Sir.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Me thinkes your faces are no such fine things now.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why did you tell mee you were wise. Lord what a lying age is this, where wil you mend these faces?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: A hogs face soust is worth a hundred of vm.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sure you had some Sow to your Mother.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: She brought such fine white pigs as you: fit for none but Parsons Ladie.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Tis wel you will alow vs our Cleargie yet.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: That shall not saue you. O that I were in loue againe with a wish.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By this light you are a scuruy fellowe, praye be gone.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: You know I am a cleane skind man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do I know it?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p:
Come, come, you would know it; thats as good: but
not a snap, neuer long for't, not a snap deare Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Harke ye Sir, harke ye, get ye to the Suburbs, there's horse-flesh for such hounds: will you goe Sir?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Lord, how I lou'd this woman, how I worshipt this pretty calfe with the white face heere: as I liue, you were the prettiest foole to play withall, the wittiest little varlet, it would talke: Lord how it talkt; and when I angred it, it would cry out, and scratch, and eate no meate, and yet would say, Goe hang.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: It will say so still, if you anger it.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: And when I askt it, if it would be married, it sent mee of an errant into France: and would abuse me, and be glad it did so.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir, this is most vnmanly, 'pray begone.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: And sweare (euen when it twitterd to be at me) I was vnhandsome.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Haue you no manners in you?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: And say my backe was melted, when the God knowes I kept it at a charge: Feure Flaunders Mares would haue beene easier to me, and a Fencer.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You thinke all this is true now.

lg.l: Faith whether it be or no, 'tis too good for you.
But so much for our mirth: Now haue at you in earnest.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: There is enough Sir, I desire no more.

lg.l: Yes faith, weele haue a cast at your best parts now,
And then the diuell take the worst.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray Sir no more, I am not much affected with your commendations: tis almost dinner, I know they stay you at the Ordinary.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: E'ene a short Grace, and then I am gone: You are a woman, and the proudest that euer lou'd a Coach: the scornfullest, scuruiest, and most scencelesse woman; the greediest to be prays'd, and neuer mou'd, though it be grosse and open; the most enuious, that at the poore fame of anothers face, would eate your owne, and more then is your owne, the paint belonging to it: of such a selfe opinion, that you thinke none can deserue your gloue: and for your malice, you are so excelient, you might haue beene your Tempters tutor: Nay, neuer cry.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Your owne heart knowes you wrong me: I cry for ye?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: You shall before I leaue you

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is all this spoke in earnest?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Yes, and more as soone as I can get it out.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, out with't.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: You are, let me see.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: One that has vs'd you with too much respect.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: One that hath vs'd me (since you will haue it so) the basest, the most Foot-boy like, without respect of what I was, or what you might be by me: you haue vs'd me, as I would vse a jade, ride him off's legges, then turn him into the Commons: you haue vs'd me with discretion, and I thanke yee. If you haue many more such prettie Seruants, pray build an Hospitall, and when they are old, keepe vm for shame.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I cannot thinke yet this is serious,

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Will you haue more on't?

lg.l: No faith, there's inough if it be true:
Too much by all my part: you are no Louer then?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: No, I had rather be a Carrier.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why the gods amend all.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Neither doe I thinke there can bee such a fellow found i'th world, to be in loue with such a froward woman: if there bee such, th'are madde, Ioue comfort vm. Now you l aue all, and I as new a man, as light, & spirited, that I feele my selfe cleane through another creature. O 'tis braue to be ones owne man. I can see you now as I would see a Picture, sit all day by you and neuer kisse your hand: heare you sing, and neuer fall backward; but with as set a temper, as I would heare a Fidler, rise and thanke you. I can now keepe my money in my purse, that still was gadding out for Scarfes and Wastcoats: and keepe my hand from Mercers sheepskins finely. I can eate Mutton now, and feast my selfe with my two shillings, and can see a Play for eighteene pence againe: I can my Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: The carriage of this fellow vexes me. Sir, pray let mee speake a little priuate with you, I must not suffer this.

lg.l: Ha, ha, ha, what would you with me?
You will not rauish me? Now, your set speech.

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Thou perjurd man.

lg.l: Ha, ha, ha, this is a fine Exordium:
And why I pray you perjurd?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Did you not sweare a thousand thousand times you lou'd me best of all things?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: I doe confesse it: make your best of that.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why doe you say, you doe not then?

lg.l: Nay Ile sweare it,
And giue sufficient reason, your owne vsage.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Doe you not loue me now then?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: No faith.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Did you euer thinke I lou'd you dearely?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Yes, but I see but rotten fruits on't.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Doe not denie your hand, for I must kisse it, and take my last farewell: now let me die so you be happy.

sp.speaker: El. lo:
sp.p: I am too foolish: Lady, speake deere Ladie.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No let me die.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O my sister.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: O my Ladie, helpe, helpe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Run for some Rosasolis.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: I haue plaid the fine asse: bend her bodie, Lady, best, dearest, worthiest Ladie, heare your seruant: I am not as I shew'd: O wretched foole to fling away the Iewel of thy life thus. Giue her more aire, see she begins to stir, sweete Mistres heare me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is my seruant well.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: In being yours I am so.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Then I care not.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: How doe ye, reach a chaire there: I confesse my fault not pardonable, in pursuing thus vpon such tendernesse my wilful errour: but had I knowne it would haue rought thus with yee, thus strangely; not the world had wonne me to it, and let not (my best Lady) any word spoke to my end disturbe your quiet peace: for sooner shall you know a generall ruine, then my faith broken. Doe not doubt this Mistres: for by my life I cannot liue without you. Come come, you shall not greeue, rather be angry, and heape infliction on me: I wil suffer. O I could curse my selfe, praye smile vpon me. Vpon my faith it was but a tricke to trie you, knowing you lou'd me dearly, and yet strangely that you would neuer shew it, though my meanes was all humilitie.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: How now?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I thanke you fine foole for your most fine plot: this was a subtile one, a stiffe deuice to haue caught Dottrels with. Good sencelesse Sir, could you imagine I should swoune for you, and know your selfe to be an arrant asse? I, a discouerd one. Tis quit I Thanke you Sir. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Take heede sir, she may chance to swoune againe?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Step to her sir, see how she changes colour.

lg.l: Ile goe to hel first, and be better welcome.
I am fool'd, I doe confesse it, finely fool'd,
Ladie fool'd Madam, and I thanke you for it.
Faith 'tis not so much worth Sir:
But if I know when you come next a burding.
Ile haue a stronger noose to hold the woodcock.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: I am glad to see you merry, pray laugh on.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Had a hard heart that could not laugh at you Sir. ha, ha.

lg.l: Praye Sister doe not laugh, youle anger him,
And then hee'l raile like a rude Costermonger,
That Schooleboies had cozned of his apples,
As loud and sencelesse.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: I will not raile.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Faith then lets heare him sister.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Yes you shall heare me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Shall we be the better for it then?

lg.l: No. He that makes a woman better by his words,
Ile haue him Sainted: blowes wil not doe it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By this light hee'l beate vs.

lg.l: You doe deserue it richly,
And may liue to haue a Beadle doe it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now he railes.

lg.l: Come scornefull Folly,
If this be railing, you shall heare me raile.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray put it in good words then.

lg.l: The worst are good enough for such a trifle,
Such a proud peece of Cobweb lawnÃ«.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You bite Sir.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: I would til the bones crackt, and I had my will.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We had best muffell him, he grows mad.

sp.speaker: El. lo
sp.p: I would twere lawfull in the next great sicknesse to haue the dogs spared; those harmelesse creatures, and knocke ith head these hot continuall plagues, weomen, that are more infectious. I hope the state will thinke on't.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Are you wel sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He lookes as though he had a greeuous fit ath Collick.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Greeneginger wil you cure me?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: He heate a trencher for him.

sp.speaker: El lo.
sp.p:
Durty December doe. Thou with a face as olde as Erra Pater, such a prognosticating nose: thou thing that ten yeares
since has left to be a woman, outworne the expectation of a Bawde; and thy dry bones can reach at nothing now, but gords or ninepinnes; pray goe fetch a trencher, goe:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Let him alone, 'is crackt:

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Ile see him hang'd first, 'is a beastly fellow, to loose a woman of my breeding thus; I marry is a: would I were a man, Ide make him eate his knaues words.

sp.speaker: Eld. L.
sp.p: Tye your she Otter vp, good Lady Folly, she stinkes worse then a beare-bayting.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why will you be angry now?

sp.speaker: Eld. L.
sp.p: Goe paint and purge, call in your kennel with you: you a Lady?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Sirra, looke too't against the quarter Sessions, if there be good behauiour in the world, Ile haue thee bound to it.

sp.speaker: Eld.
sp.p: L. You must not seeke it in your Ladyes house then: pray send this Ferret home, and spinne good Abigall. And Maddame, that your Ladyshippe may know, in what base manner you haue vs'd my seruice, I doe from this hower hate thee heartily: and though your folly should whip you to repentance. and waken you at length to see my wronges, tis not the indeauour of your life shall win me: not all the friends you haue in intercession, nor your submissiue letters, though they spoke as many teares as words; not your knees growne toth' ground in penitence, not all your state, to kisse you: nor my pardon nor will to giue you Christian buriall, if you dye thus: so farewell. When I am marryed and made sure, Ile come and visit you againe, and vexe you Lady. By all my hopes Ile be a torment to you, worse then a tedious winter. I know you will recant and sue to me, but saue that labour: Ile rather loue a Feuer and continuall thirst, rather contract my youth to drinke, and safer dote vpon quarrells, or take a drawne whore from an Hospitall, that time, diseases, and Mercury had eaten, then to be drawne to loue you.

sp.speaker: La,
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, pray doe, but take heed though.

sp.speaker: Eld. L.
sp.p: From thee, false dice, lades. Cowards, and plaguy Summers, good Lord deliuer mee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But harke you seruant, harke ye: is he gone? call him aine:

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Hang him Padocke.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Art thou here still? fly, fly, and call my seruant, fly or nere see me more.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I had rather knit againe then see that rascall, but I must doe it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I would be loth to anger him too much: what fine foolery is this in a woman, to vse those men most frowardly they loue most? If I should loose him thus, I were rightly serued. I hope is not so much himselfe to take it to'th heart: how now? will he come backe?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Neuer he sweares whilst he can heare men say ther's any woman liuing: he swore hee wood ha me first.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Didst thou intreat him wench?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: As well as I could Madam. But this is still your way, to loue being absent, and when hee's with you, laugh at him and abuse him. There is another way if you could hit on't.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou saist true, get me paper, pen, and inke, Ile write to him, Ide be loth he should sleepe in's anger.
Women are most fooles, when they thinke th'are wisest.

div.stage: Musicke. Enter young Louelesse and Widdow, going to be married: with them his Comrades.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Pray Sir cast off these fellowes, as vnfitting for your bare knowledge, and farre more your company: ist fit such Ragamuffins as these are should beare the name of friends? and furnish out a ciuill house? y'are to be marryed now, and men that loue you must expect a course farre from your old carrire: If you will keepe vm, turne vm toth' stable, & there make vm groomes: and yet now I consider it, such beggars once set a horse back, you haue heard will ride, how farre you had best to looke to.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Heare you, you that must be Lady, pray content your selfe and thinke vpon your carriage soone at night, what dressing will best take your knight, what wastcote, what cordiall will doe well i'th morning for him, what tryers haue you?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: What doe you meane Sir?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Those that must switch him vp: if he start well, feare not but cry S. George, and beare him hard: when you perceiue his wind growes hot, and wanting, let him a little downe, 'is fleet nere doubt him, and stands sound.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Sir, you heare these fellowes?

sp.speaker: Yo. L.
sp.p: Merry companions, wench, merry companions:

sp.speaker: UUi.
sp.p: To one another let vm be companions, but good Sir not to you: you shall be ciuill and slip off these base trappings.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: He shall not need, my most sweet Lady grocer, if hee be ciuill, not your powdered Suger, nor your Reasens shall perswade the Captaine to liue a Coxcome with him: Let him be ciuill and eate i'th Arches, and see what will come ont.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: I et him bee ciuill, doe: vndoe him: I, thats the next way. I will not take (if hee be ciuill once) two hundred pounds a yeare to liue with him: bee ciuill? theres a trimme perswasion.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: If thou beest ciuill Knight, as Ioue defend it, get thee another nose, that wil be puld off by the angry boyes, for thy conuersion: the Children thou shalt get on this Ciuilian cannot inherit by the law, th'are Ethnickes, and all thy sport meere Morrall lechery: when they are growne hauing but little in vm, they may prooue Haberdashers, or grosse Grosers, like their deare damme there: prethe be ciuill Knight, in time thou maist read to thy houshold and be drunke once a yeare: this would shew finely.

sp.speaker: Yo. L.
sp.p: I wonder sweet heart you will offer this, you doe not vnderstand these Gentlemen: I will be short and pithy: I had rather cast you off by the way of charge: these are Creatures, that nothing goes to the maintenance of but Corne and Water. I will keepe these fellowes just in the Competency of two Hennes:

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If you can cast it so Sir, you haue my liking; if they eat lesse, I should not be offended: But how these, Sir, can liue vppon so little as Corne and Water. I am vnbeleeuing.

sp.speaker: Yo. L.
sp.p: Why prethee sweet heart what's your Ale? is not that Corne and Water my sweet Widdow?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I but my sweet Knight, wheres the meat to this, and cloathes that they must looke for?

sp.speaker: Yo. L.
sp.p:
In the short sentence Ale, is all included: Meate, Drinke, and Cloth: these are no rauening foot-men, no fellowes that at Ordinaries dare eat their eighteene pence thrice out before they rise, and yet goe hungry to play, and crack more nuts then would suffice a dozen Squirrels; besides the din,
which is damnable: I had rather raile, and be confin'd to a Boat maker, then hue among such rascalls; these are people of such a cleane discretion in their dyet, of such a moderate sustenance, that they sweat if they but smell hot meate. Porredge is poyson, they hate a kitchen as they hate a counter, and show em but a Fetherbed they swound. Ale is their eating, and their drinking surely, which keeps their bodies cleere, & soluble. Bread is a binder, and for that abolisht euen in their ale, whose lost roome fills an apple, which is more ayre, and of subtiller Nature. The rest they take, is little, and that little, as little easie: For like strict men of order, they doe correct their bodies with a bench, or a poore stubborne table; if a chimney offer it self with some few broken rushes, they are in downe: when they are sick, that's drunke, they may haue fresh shaw, else they doe despise these worldly pamperings. For their poore apparrell, tis worne out to the dyet; new they seeke none, and if a man should offer, they are angry: scarse to be reconcyl'd againe with him: you shall not heare em aske one a cast doublet, once in a yeare, which is a modesty befitting my poore friends: you see their Wardrope, though slender, competent: For shirts I take it, they are things worne out of their remembrance. Lowsie they will be, when they list, and Mangie, which showes a fine variety: and then to cure em, a Tanners lymepit, which is little charge, two dogs, and these; these two may be cur'd for three pence.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: You haue halfe perswaded me, pray vse your pleasure: and my good friends since I doe know your dyet, Ile take an order, meate shall not offend you, you shall haue ale.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Wee aske no more, let it be mighty, Lady: and if wee perish, then our owne sinnes on vs.

sp.speaker: Yo. l.
sp.p: Come forward gentlemen, to Church my boyes, when we haue done, Ile giue you cheere in boules.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p:
This senselesse woman vexes me toth' heart, she will not from my memory: would she were a man for one two houres, that I might beate her. If I had bin vnhansome, old, or t'had
bin an euen lay she might haue scorn'd me: but to be yong, and by this light I thinke as proper as the proudest; made as cleane, as straight, and strong backt; meanes and manners equall with the best cloth of siluer Sir i'th kingdome: But these are things at some time of the Moone, below the cut of Canuas: Sure shee has some Mecching raskall in her house, some hinde, that she hath seene beare (like another Milo) quarters of Malte vpon his backe, and sing with't, thrash all day, and ith euening in his stockings, strike vp a hornepipe, and there stink two houres, and nere a whit the worse man; these are they, these steele chind rascalls that vndoe vs all. Would I had bin a carter, or a Coachman, I had done the deed ere this time:

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir ther's a Gentleman without would speak with you:

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: Bid him come in:

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: By your leaue Sir.

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: You are welcome, whats your will Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Haue you forgotten me?

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: I doe not much remember you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You must Sir. I am that gentleman you pleasd to wrong, in your disguise I haue inquired you out.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: I was disguised indeed Sir if I wrongd you. Pray where and when?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: In such a Ladies house Sir: I need not name her.

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: I doe remember you: you seem'd to be a suter to that Lady:

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: If you remember this, doe not forget how scuruyly you vsd me: that was no place to quarrell in, pray you thinke of it: If you be honest you dare fight with me, without more viging, else I must prouoke yee:

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p:
Sir I dare fight, but neuer for a woman, I will not haue her in my cause, she's Mortall and so is not my anger: If you haue brought a Nobler subiect for our swords, I am for you: in this I would be loth to prick my finger. And where you say I wrongd you, 'tis so far from my profession, that amongst my feares, to doe wrong is the greatest: credit me we haue bin both abusd. (not by our selues, for that I hold a spleene no sinne of Mallice, and may with man enough be lest forgotten,) but by that wilfull, scornefull peece of hatred, that much forgetfull Lady: For whose
sake, if we should leaue our reason, and runne on vpon our sense, like Rams: the little world of good men would laugh at vs, and despise vs, fixing vpon our desperate memories the neuer-worne out names of Fooles, and Fencers. Sir tis not feare, but reason makes me tell you: in this I had rather helpe you Sir, then hurt you, and you shall finde it, though you throw your selfe into as many dangers as she offers, though you redeeme her lost name euery day, and finde her out new honours with your sworde, you shall but be her mitth, as I haue bin.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I aske you mercy Sir, you haue tane my edge off: yet I would faine be euen with this Lady.

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: In which ile be your helper: we are two, and they are two: two sisters, rich alike, onely the elder has the prouder dowry: In troth I pitty this disgrace in you, yet of mine owne I am senselesse: doe but follow my counsell, and ile pawne my spirit, we'le ouerreach em yet; the meanes is this.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir theres a Gentlewoman will needs speake with you: I cannot keep her out, she's entered Sir:

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: It is the waiting woman, pray be not seene: sirra hold her in discourse awhile: harke in your eare, goe, and dispatch it quickly, when I come in Ile tell you all the proiect.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I care not which I haue.

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: Away, tis done, she must not see you: now Lady Gwiniuer, what newes with you?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Pray leaue these frumps Sir, and receiue this letter.

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: From whom good vanity?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: 'Tis from my Lady Sir: alas good soule, shee cries and takes on:

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: Do's she so good soule? wod she not haue a Cawdle? do's she send you with your fine Oratory goody Tully to tye me to beleife againe? Bring out the Cat hounds, ile make you take a tree whore, then with my tyller bring downe your Gibship, and then haue you cast, and hung vp ith warren.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I am no beast Sir: would you knew it:

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: Wod I did, for I am yet very doubtfull: what will you say now?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Nothing not I:

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: Art thou a woman, and say nothing?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Vnlesse youle heare mee with more moderation; I can speake wise enough:

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: And loud enough: will your Lady loue me?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: It seemes so by her letter, and her lamentations: but you are such another man:

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: Not such another as I was, Mumps; nor will not be: ile reade her fine Epistle: ha, ha, ha: is not thy Mistresse mad?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: For you she will be, 'tis a shame you should vse a poore gentlewoman so vntowardly: she loues the ground you tread on: and you (hard hart) because she iested with you, meane to kill her: 'tis a fine conquest as they say:

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: Hast thou so much moysture in thy whitleather hyde yet, that thou can'st cry? I wod haue sworne thou hadst beene touchwood fiue yeare since: Nay let it raine, thy Face chops for a shower like a dry dunghyll.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Ile not endure this Ribaldry: Farwell ith' Diuels name: if my Lady die, ile be sworne before a Iurye, thou art the cause on't:

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: Doe Maukin doe: deliuer to your Lady from me this: I meane to see her, if I haue no other businesse; which before ile want to come to her, I meane to goe seeke byrds nests: yet I may come too: but if I come, from this doore till I see her, will I thinke how to raile vildly at her; how to vex her, and make her cry so much, that the Phisition if she fall sick vpon't shall want vryne to finde the cause by: and she remedilesse die in her heresie: Farwell old Adage, I hope to see the boyes make Potguns on thee.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Th'art a vyle man; God blesse my issue from thee.

sp.speaker: Eld. lo.
sp.p: Thou hast but one, and thats in thy left crupper, that makes thee hobble so; you must be ground ith breech like a top, youle nere spin well else: Farwell Fytchocke.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Is it not strange that euery womans will should tracke out new waies to disturbe her selfe? if I should call my reason to accoumpt, it cannot answere why I stoppe my selfe from mine owne wish; and stoppe the man I loue from his; and euery houre repent againe, yet still goe on: I know 'tis like a man, that wants his naturall sleep, and growing dull, would gladly giue the remnant of his life for two howers rest: yet through his frowardnesse, will rather chuse to watch another man.
Drowsie as he, then take his owne repose. All this I know: yet a strange peuishnes and anger, not to haue the power to doe thinges vnexpected, carryes me away to mine owne ruine had rather dye sometimes then not disgrace in publike him whom people thinke I loue, and doo't with oaths, and am in earnest then: O what are wee! Men, you must answer this, that do obey such thinges as wee command. How now? what newes?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Faith Madam none worth hearing.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is he not come?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: No truly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nor has he writ?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Neither. I pray God you haue not vndone your selfe:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why, but what sayes hee?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Faith he talkes strangely:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How strangely?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: First at your Letter he laught extreamly:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What in contempt?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: He laught monstrous loud, as he would dye, and when you wrote it, I thinke you were in no such merry mood, to prouoke him that way: and hauing done he cryed alas for her, and violently laught againe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Did he?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: yes till I was angry:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Angry, why? why wert thou angry? he did doe but well, I did deserue it, hee had beene a foole, an vnfit man for any one to loue, had he not laught thus at mee: you were angry, that show'd your folly; I shall loue him more for that, then all that ere he did before: but said he nothing else?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: Many vncertaine things: he said though you had mock't him, because you were a woman, he could wish to doe you so much fauour as to see you: yet he said, he knew you rash, and was loth to offend you with the sight of one, whom now he was bound not to leaue.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What one was that?

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: I know not, but truely I doe feare there is a making vp there: for I heard the seruants, as I past by some, whisper such a thing: and as I came backe through the hall, there were two or three Clarkes writing great conueyances in hast, which they said were for their Mistris ioynture.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: 'Tis very like and fit it should be so, for he does thinke, and reasonably thinke, that I should keepe him with my idle tricks for euer ere he maried.

sp.speaker: Abi.
sp.p: At last he said, it should goe hard but he would see you for your satisfaction.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: All we that are cal'd Women, know as well as men, it were a farre more Noble thing to grace where wee are grac't, and giue respect there where wee are respected: yet we practise a wilder course, and neuer bend our eyes on men with pleasure, till they finde the way to giue vs a neglect: then we, too late, perceiue the losse of what we might haue had, and dote to death.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Sister yonders your Seruant, with a gentlewoman with him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Close at the dore.

lg.l: Ahlas I am vndone, I feare he is betroth'd.
What kind of woman is she?
A most ill fauoured one, with her Masque on:
And how her face should mend the rest I know not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But yet her minde is of a milder stuffe then mine was.

div.stage: Enter Fld Louelesse, and Welford in womans apparrell.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now I see him, if my heart swell not againe (away thou womans pride) so that I cannot speake a gentle word to him, let me not liue.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: By your leaue here.

lg.l: How now, what new tricke inuites you hither?
Ha' you a fine deuice againe?
Faith this is the finest deuice I haue now:
How dost thou sweet heart?
Why very well, so long as I may please
You my deare Louer: I nor can, nor will
Be ill when you are well, well when you are ill.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: O thy sweet temper: what would I haue giuen, that lady had beene like thee: seest thou her? that face (my loue) joynd with thy humble minde, had made a wench indeede.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Alas my loue, what God hath done, I dare not thinke to mend: I vse no paint, nor any drugs of Arte, my hands and face will shew it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why what thing haue you brought to shew vs there? doe you take money for it?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: A Godlike thing, not to be bought for money: tis my Mistres: in whom there is no passions, nor no scorne: what I will is for law; pray you salute her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Salute her? by this good light I would not kisse her for halfe my wealth.

lg.l: Why, why pray you?
You shall see me do't afore you: looke you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now fie vpon thee, a beast would not haue done I would not kisse thee of a month to gaine a Kingdome.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Marry you shall not be troubled.

lg.l: Why was there euer such a Meg as this?
Sure thou art madde.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: I was mad once, when I lou'd pictures: for what are shape and colours else, but pictures? in that tawny hide there lies an endles masse of vertues; when all your red & white ones want it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And this is she you are to marry, is't not?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Yes indeed is't.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: God giue you joy.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Amen.

lg.l: I thanke you, as vnknowne, for your good wish.
The like to you, when euer you shall wed.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: O gentle spirit.

lg.l: You thanke me? I pray
Keepe your breath neerer you, I doe not like it.
I would not willingly offend at all:
Much lesse a lady of your worthy parts.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Sweet, Sweet.

lg.l: I doe not thinke this woman can by nature be thus,
Thus vgly: sure shee's some common Strumpet,
Deform'd with exercise of sinne.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O Sir beleeue not this: for heauen so comfort me as I am free from foule pollution with any man: my honour tane away, I am no woman.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Arise my dearest soule: I doe not credit it. Alas, I feare her tender heart will breake with this reproach: fie that you know no more ciuillitie to a weake virgin. Tis no matter Sweet, let her say what she will, thou art not worse to me, and therefore not at all: be carelesse.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: For all things else I would, but for mine honour: Me thinks.

lg.l: Alas, thine honour is not stain'd.
Is this the businesse that you sent for me about?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Faith Sister you are much to balme, to vse a woman, whatsoe're she be, thus: we salute her: You are welcome hither.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I humbly thanke you.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p:
Milde still as the Doue, for all these iniuries. Come, shall
we goe, I loue thee not so ill to keepe thee here a jesting stocke. Adue to the worlds end.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why whither now?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Nay you shal neuer know, because you shal not finde me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I pray let me speake with you.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Tis very well: come.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I pray you let me speake with you.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Yes for another mocke.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By heauen I haue no mocks: good Sir a word.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Though you deserue not so much at my hands, yet if you be in such earnest, I will speake a word with you: but I beseech you bee briefe; for in good faith there's a Parson, and a licence stay for vs i'th Church all this while: & you know tis night.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir, giue mee hearing patiently, and whatsoeuer I haue heretofore spoke jestingly, forget: for as I hope for mercy any where, what I shall vtter now is from my heart, and as I meane.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Well, well, what doe you meane?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Was not I once your Mistres, and you my Seruant?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: O 'tis about the old matter.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay good Sir stay me out: I would but heare you excuse your selfe, why you should take this woman, and leaue me.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Prethee why not, deserues she not as much as you?

lg.l: I thinke not, if you will looke
With an indifferencie vp on vs both.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Vpon your faces, tis true: but if judicially we shall cast our eies vpon your mindes, you are a thousand weomen of her in worth: Shee cannot sound in jest, nor set her louer tasks, to shew her peuishnes, and his affection: nor crosse what he saies, though it bee Canonicoll. Shee's a good plaine wench, that will doe as I will haue her, and bring mee lusty boyes to throw the Sledge, and lift at Pigs of lead: and for a wife, shee's farre beyond you: what can you doe in a houshold, to prouide for your issue, but lye a bed and get vm? your businesse is to dresse you, and at idle houres to eate; when she can doe a thousand profitable things: She can doe pretty well in the Pastry, and knows how pullen should be cram'd: she cuts Cambricke at a thrid: weaues bone-lace, and quilts balls: And what are you good for?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Admit it true, that she were farre beyond me in all respects, do'es that giue you a licence to forsweare your selfe?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Forsweare my selfe, how?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Perhaps you haue forgot the innumerable oathes you haue vttered in disclaiming all for wiues but me: Ile not remember you: God giue you ioy.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Nay but conceiue mee, the intent of oaths is euer vnderstood. Admit I should protest to such a friend, to see him at his lodging to morrow: Diuines would neuer hold me periur'd, if I were struck blinde, or he hid him where my diligent search could not finde him: so there were no crosse act of mine owne in't. Can it bee imagined I meant to force you to marriage, and to haue you whether you will or no?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Alas you neede not. I make already tender of my selfe, and then you are forsworne.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Some sinne I see indeede must necessarily fall vpon me, as whosoeuer deals with women shal neuer vtterly auoide it: yet I would chuse the least ill; which is to forsake you, that haue done me all the abuses of a malignant woman, contemn'd my seruice, and would haue held me prating about marriage, till I had beene past getting of children: then her that hath forsooke her family, and put her tender bodie in my hand, vpon my word.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Which of vs swore you first to?

sp.speaker: El. lo:
sp.p: Why to you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Which oath is to be kept then.

lg.l: I prethee doe not vrge my sinnes vnto me,
Without I could amend vm.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why you may by wedding me.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: How will that satisfie my word to her?

lg.l: Tis not to be kept, and needs no satisfaction,
Tis an error fit for repentance onely.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Shall I liue to wrong that tender hearted virgin so? It may not be.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why may it not be?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: I sweare I had rather marry thee then her: but yet mine honesty.

lg.l: What honesty? Tis more preseru'd this way:
Come, by this light seruant thou shalt, Ile kisse thee on't.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: This kisse indeede is sweet, pray God no sin lie vnder it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: There is no sinne at all, trie but another.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O my heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Helpe sister, this ladie swounes.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: How doe you?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why very well, if you be so.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Sure a quiet minde liues not in any woman: I shal doe a most vngodly thing. Heare me one word more, which by all my hopes I will not alter. I did make an oath when you delaid me so; that this very night I would be married. Now if you will goe without delay, suddenly, as late as it is, with your owne Minister to your owne Chappel, Ile wed you, and to bed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A match deare seruant.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: For if you should forsake me now, I care not, she would not though for all her iniuries, such is her spirit, If I bee not ashamed to kisse her now I part, may I not liue.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I see you goe, as sliely as you thinke to steale away: yet I wil pray for you; All blessings of the world light on you two, that you may liue to be an aged paire. Al curses on me if I doe not speake what I doe wish indeede.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: If I can speake to purpose to her, I am a villaine.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Seruant away.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sister, wil you marry that inconstant man? thinke you he wil not cast you off to morrow, to wrong a ladie thus, lookt she like durt, twas basely done. May you nere prosper with him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Now God forbid, Alas I was vnworthy, so I told him.

lg.l: That was your modesty, too good for him.
I would not see your wedding for a world.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Chuse, chuse, come Yongloue.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Drie vp your eies forsooth, you shall not thinke we are all vnciuill, all such beasts as these. Would I knew how to giue you a reuenge.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: So would not I: No let me suffer truly, that I desire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray walke in with me, tis very late, and you shal stay all night: your bed shal be no worse then mine; I wish I could but doe you right.

lg.l: My humble thankes:
God grant I may but liue to quit your loue.

sp.speaker: Young lo.
sp.p: Did your Master send for me Sauil?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes he did send for your worship sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo.
sp.p: Doe you know the businesse?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
Alas Sir I know nothing, nor am imployed beyond my
howers of eating. My dancing daies are done sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo.
sp.p: What art thou now then.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: If you consider me in little, I am with your worships reuerence sir, a rascal: one that vpon the next anger of your brother, must raise a sconce by the high way, and sel switches. My wife is learning new sir to weaue inckle.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo.
sp.p: What dost thou meane to doe with thy children Sauill?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: My eldest boy is halfe a rouge already, he was borne bursten, and your worship knowes, that is a pretty steppe to mens capassions. My youngest boy I purpose sir to binde for ten yeeres to a Ioaler, to drawe vnder him, that he may shew vs mercy in his function.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo.
sp.p: Your family is quartered with discretion: you are resolued to cant then: where Sauil shall your sceane lie.

lg.l: Beggars must be no choosers:
In euery place (I take it) but the stockes.
This is your drinking, and your whoring Sauil,
I tould you of it, but your heart was hardned.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Tis true, you were the first that tolde me of it, I doe remember yet in teares, you told me you would haue whores, and in that passion sir, you broke our thus; Thou miserable man, repent, and brew three strikes more in a hogshed. Tis noone ere we be drunke now, and the time can tarry for no man.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo.
sp.p: Y'are growne a bitter Gentleman. I see misery can can cleere your head better then mustard. Ile be a sutor for your keyes againe sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Wil you but be so gratious to me sir? I shal be bound.

lg.l: You shall sir,
To your bunch againe, or I'le misse fouly.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Saue you gent. saue you.

sp.speaker: Yo lo.
sp.p: Now Pole-cat, what young Rabets nest haue you to drawe?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Come, pre thee bee familiar Knight.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo!
sp.p: Away Fox, Ile send for Terriers for you.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Thou art wide yet: Ile keepe thee companie.

lg.l: I am about some businesse; Indentures,
If ye follow me Ile beate you: take heede,
As I liue Ile cancell your Coxcombe.
Thou art cozen'd now, I am no vsurer:
What poore fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I am poore indeede sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Giue him money Knight.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo.
sp.p: Doe you begin the offring.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: There pore fellow, heer's an angel for thee.

sp.speaker: Yo lo.
sp.p: Art thou in earnest Moorcraft?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Yes faith Knight. Ile follow thy example: thou hadst land and thousands, thou spendst, and flungst away, and yet it flowes in double: I purchasde, wrung, and wierdraw'd for my wealth, lost, and was cozend: for which I make a vowe, to trie all the waies aboue ground. but Ile finde a constant meanes to riches without curses.

lg.l: I am glad of your conuersion Mr. Moorcraft:
y'are in a faire course, praye pursue it still.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Come, we are all gallants now, Ile keepe thee company; Heere honest fellow, for this gentlemans sake, theres two angels more for thee.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: God quit you sir, and keepe you longe in this minde.

sp.speaker: Yr. lo.
sp.p: Wilt thou perseuer?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Til I haue a penny. I haue braue clothes a making, and two horses; canst thou not helpe me to a Match Knight, Ile lay a a thousand pound vpon my crop-eare.

lg.l: Foote this is stranger then an Affrick monster,
There will be no more talke of the Cleaue wars
Whilst this lasts, come, Ile put thee into blood.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Would all his damb'd tribe were as tender hearted. I beseech you let this gent. ioyne with you in the recouery of my Keyes; I like his good beginning sir, the whilst Ile pray for both your worships.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo.
sp.p: He shall sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Shall we goe noble Knight? I would faine be acquainted.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo.
sp.p: Ile be your seruant sir.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Faith my sweet Ladie, I haue caught you now, mauger your subtilities, and fine deuises, be coy againe now.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Prethee sweeteheart tell true.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: By this light, by all the pleasures I haue had this night, by your lost maidenhead, you are cozend meerely. I haue cast beyond your wit. That gent. is your retainer Welford.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: It cannot be so.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p:
Your sister has found it so, or I mistake: marke how she
blushes when you see her next. Ha, ha, ha, I shall not trauell now, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Prethee sweet heart be quiet, thou hast angerd me at heart.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Ile please you soone againe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Welford.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: I Welford, hee's a young hansome fellow, well bred and landed: your sister can instruct you in his good parts better then I by this time.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Vdsfoote, am I fetcht ouer thus?

lg.l: Yes ifaith.
And ouer shall be fetcht againe, neuer feare it.
I must be patient, though it torture me:
You haue got the Sunne Sir.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: And the Moone too, in which Ile be the man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But had I knowne this, had I but surmiz'd it, you should haue hunted three traines more, before you had come to'th course, you should haue hanckt o'th bridle, Sir, ifaith.

lg.l: I knew it, and min'd with you, and so blew you vp.
Now you may see the Gentlewoman: stand close.
For Gods sake Sir be priuate in this busines,
You haue vndone me else. O God, what haue I done?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No harme I warrant thee.

lg.l: How shall I looke vpon my friends againe?
With what face?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why e'ne with that: tis a good one, thou canst not finde a better: looke vpon all the faces thou shalt see there, and you shall finde vm smooth still, faire still, sweet still, and to your thinking honest: those haue done as much as you haue yet, or dare doe Mistres, and yet they keepe no stirre.

lg.l: Good Sir goe in, and put your womans cloathes on.
If you be seene thus, I am lost for euer.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Ile watch you for that Mistres: I am no foole, heere will I tarry till the house be vp and witnes with me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good deare friend goe in.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p:
To bed againe if you please, else I am fixt heere, till there be notice taken what I am, and what I haue done: If you could iuggle me into my woman-hood againe, & so cog me out of your company, all this would be forsworne, and I againe an asinego, as your Sister left me. No, Ile haue it knowne and publisht; then if
you'le be a whore, forsake me, & be sham'd: & when you can hold out no longer, marry some cast Cleue Captaine, and sell Bottle-ale.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I dare not stay sir, vse me modestly, I am your wife.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Goe in, Ile make vp all.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Ile be a witnes to your naked truth Sir: this is the gentlewoman, prethee looke vpon him, this is he that made me breake my faith Sweet: but thanke your sister, she hath soderd it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What a dull asse was I, I could not see this wencher from a wench: twentie to one, if I had beene but tender like my sister, he had serued me such a slippery tricke too.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Twenty to one I had.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: I would haue watcht you Sir, by your good patience, for ferretting in my ground.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yow haue beene with my Sister.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Yes, to bring.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: An heire into the world he meanes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: There is no chafing now.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I haue had my part on't: I haue beene chaft this three houres, thats the least, I am reasonable coole now.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Cannot you fare well, but you must cry rost-meat?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: He that fares well, and will not blesse the founders, is either surfetted, or ill taught, Ladie: for mine owne part, I haue found so sweet a diet, I can commend it, though I cannot spare it.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: How like you this dish, Welford, I made a supper on't, and fed so heartily, I could not sleepe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By this light, had I but sented out your traine, ye had slept with a bare pillow in your armes, & kist that, or else the bed-post, for any wife yee had got this twelue-month yet: I would haue vext you more then a tyr'd post-horse: & bin longer bearing, then euer after-game at Irish was. Lord, that I were vnmaried againe.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Lady, I would not vndertake yee, were you againe a Haggard, for the best cast of sore Ladies i'th Kingdome: you were euer tickle footed, and would not trusse round?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Is she fast?

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: She was all night lockt here boy.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Then you may lure her without feare of loosing: take off her Cranes. You haue a delicate Gentlewoman to your sister: Lord what a pretty fury she was in, when she perceiued I was a man: but I thanke God I satisfied her scruple, without the Parson o'th towne.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: What did ye?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Maddame, can you tell what we did?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: She has a shrewd guesse at it I see by her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well you may mocke vs: but my large Gentlewoman, my Mary Ambree, had I but seene into you, you should haue had another bedfellow, fitter a great deale for your itch.

lg.l: I thanke you Lady, me thought it was well,
You are so curious.

div.stage: Enter Young Louelesse, his Lady, Moorecraft, Sauill and two Seruingmen.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Get on your dublet, here comes my brother.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Good morrow brother, and all good to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: God saue you, and good morrow to you all.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Good morrow. Here's a poore brother of yours.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Fie how this shames me.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Prethee good fellow helpe me to a cup of Beere.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will Sir,

lg.l: Brother what make you here? will this Lady doe?
Will she? is she not nettel'd still?
No, I haue cur'd her.
Mr. Welford, pray know this Gentleman, is my brother.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir, I shall long to loue him.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo.
sp.p: I shall not be your debter Sir. But how is't with you?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: As well as may bee man; I am married: your new acquaintance hath her Sister: and all's well.

lg.l: I am glad on't. Now my pretty Lady Sister,
How doe you finde my brother?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Almost as wilde as you are.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: A will make the better husband: you haue tride him?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Against my will Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Hee'le make your will amends soone, doe not doubt it. But Sir, I must intreat you to be better knowne To this conuerted Iew here.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here's Beere for you Sir.

lg.l: And here's for you an angell:
Pray buy no Land, twill neuer prosper Sir.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: Blesse you, and then Ile tell: He's turn'd Gallant.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Gallant?

lg.l: I Gallant, and is now called, Cutting Moorecraft:
The reason Ile informe you, at more leisure,

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: O good Sir let me know him presently.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo.
sp.p: You shall hug one an other.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Sir I must keepe you company.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: And reason.

sp.speaker: Yo. lo.
sp.p: Cutting Moorcraft faees about. I must present another.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: As many as you will Sir, I am for vm.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir I shall doe you seruice.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I shal looke for't in good faith sir.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: Prethee good sweet-heart kisse him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Who, that fellow?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir will it please you to remember me: my keyes good sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: I'le doe it presently.

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: Come thou shalt kisse him for our sport sake.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Let him come on then, and doe you heare, doe not instruct me in these tricks, for you may repent it.

lg.l: That at my perill. Lusty Mr. Moorecraft,
Heere is a Ladie would salute you.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: She shall not loose her longing Sir: what is she?

sp.speaker: El. Lo.
sp.p: My wife Sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: She must be then my Mistres.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Must I Sir:

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: O yes, you must.

lg.l: And you must take this ring, a poore pawne,
Of some fifty pound.

sp.speaker: El. lo:
sp.p: Take it by any meanes, tis lawfull prise.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir I shall call you seruant.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I shall be proud on't: what fellow's that:

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: My Ladies Coach-man.

lg.l: Ther's something. (my friend) for you to buy whips,
And for you sir, and you sir.
Vnder a miracle this is the strangest,
I euer heard of.
What shall we play, or drinke? what shall we doe?
Who will hunt with me for a hundred pound?
Stranger and Stranger!
Sir you shall finde sport after a day or two.
Sir I haue a sute vnto you,
Concerning your old seruant Sauill.

sp.speaker: El. lo.
sp.p: O, for his keyes, I know it,

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Now sir, strike in.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Sir I must haue you grant me.

lg.l: Tis done Sir, take your keyes againe:
But harke you Sauill, leaue of the motions
Of the flesh, and be honest, or else you shall graze againe.
Ile trie you once more.
If euer I be taken drunke, or whoring,
Take off the biggest key i'th bunch, and open
My head with it Sir: I humbly thanke your worships.
Nay then I see we must keepe holiday Ent. Roger, & Abigall.
Heers the last couple in hell.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Ioy be amongst you all.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why how now sir, what is the meaning of this Embleme?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Marriage an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Are you married?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: As well as the next priest could doe it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Eld. Lo.
sp.p: I thinke the signes in Gemini heer's such coupling.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Sir Roger, what will you take to lie from your sweete-heart to night?

sp.speaker: Ro
sp.p: Not the best benifice in your worships gift Sir.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: A whorson, how he swels.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: How many times to night Sir Roger?

lg.l: Sir you grow scurrilous:
What I shall doe, I shall doe: I shall not neede your helpe.

sp.speaker: Yo. Lo.
sp.p: For horse flesh Roger.

lg.l: Come prethee be not angry, tis a day
Giuen wholly to our mirth.
It shall be so sir: Sir Roger and his Bride,
We shall intreate to be at our charge.
Welford get you to Church: by this light,
You shall not lie with her againe, till y'are married.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I am gone.

lg.l: To euery Bride I dedicate this day:
Six healths a peece, and it shall goe hard,
But euery one a Iewell: Come be mad Boyes.
Th'art in a good beginning: come who leads?
Sir Roger, you shall haue the Van: leade the way:
Would euery dogged wench had such a day. Exeunt.
